{{See also|2009 flu pandemic timeline|2009 flu pandemic tables|2009 flu pandemic summary}} {{pp-move-indef}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2012}} {{Update|date=November 2010}} This article deals with the status and efforts regarding the '''[[2009 flu pandemic]] '''by country and continent/region. {{2009-2010 flu pandemic table}} [[File:H1N1 map.svg|300px|thumb|left| {{legend|#000000|Confirmed cases followed by death}} {{legend|#FF0000|Confirmed cases}} {{legend|#FFA900|Unconfirmed or suspected cases}} See also: [http://www.theairdb.com/swine-flu/heatmap.html H1N1 live map], [http://www.who.int/csr/don/ WHO updates] ]] [[File:H1N1 map by confirmed deaths.svg|300px|thumb|left| {{legend|forestgreen|0 deaths}} {{legend|brown|suspected deaths}} {{legend|#e0e0e0|1+ deaths}} {{legend|#c0c0c0|5+ deaths}} {{legend|#a0a0a0|10+ deaths}} {{legend|#909090|50+ deaths}} {{legend|#707070|100+ deaths}} {{legend|#505050|500+ deaths}} See also: [http://www.theairdb.com/swine-flu/heatmap.html H1N1 live map], [http://www.who.int/csr/don/ WHO updates] ]] [[File:H1N1 map by confirmed community outbreaks.svg|300px|thumb|left|{{legend|#ff6600|Confirmed community outbreaks}} See also: [http://www.theairdb.com/swine-flu/heatmap.html H1N1 live map], [http://www.who.int/csr/don/ WHO updates] ]] [[File:Countries with confirm mutation of swine flu.png|300px|thumb|left|{{legend|purple|Confirmed mutation of H1N1 virus}}]] [[File:Countries with confirm double cases of swine flu.png|300px|thumb|left|{{legend|grey|Confirmed double infections}}]] [[File:Countries with confirm tamiflu resistance of swine flu.png|300px|thumb|left|{{legend|yellow|Confirmed cases of tamiflu resistance}}]] As the [[pandemic]] progressed, laboratory testing and confirmation decreased. Confirmed figures for the [[2009 flu pandemic in the United Kingdom|United Kingdom]], in particular, are only meaningful up to 2 July, when routine testing stopped and presumed cases were treated without laboratory confirmation of diagnosis. Following the recommendations of the [[World Health Organization]] (WHO), many countries stopped issuing estimates of the infected population, making this list inaccurate. {| class="wikitable sortable" |+ The ten countries and territories with most confirmed cases per capita ! class="unsortable" style="text-align:center;"| Pos. ! '''2009 flu pandemic
in Africa:'''
{{legend|#000000|Confirmed deaths}}{{legend|#cd3412|Confirmed cases}}{{legend|#ffcd00|Suspect cases}}{{legend|silver|No reported cases}}]] |[[File:H1N1 Africa Map by confirmed deaths.svg|thumb|center|{{legend|forestgreen|No deaths}}{{legend|#e6e6e6|1+ deaths}}{{legend|#cccccc|5+ deaths}}{{legend|#b3b3b3|10+ deaths}}{{legend|#999999|50+ deaths}}{{legend|#808080|100+ deaths}}]] |} The Egyptian government ordered the mass slaughter of all pigs in Egypt on 29 April,{{cite web |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/04/30/2556545.htm?section=justin%20Egypt%20orders%20pig%20cull |title=Egypt orders pig cull – ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation) |publisher=ABC |location=Australia |accessdate=27 September 2009 }} even though the current strain was a human-human transmittable, human [[influenza]] that had previously hybridized with [[avian flu]] and [[swine flu]]. The [[World Organization for Animal Health]] called the swine killing "scientifically unjustified".{{cite news |authorlink= | title=OIE position on safety of international trade of pigs and products of pig origin | date=28 April 2009 | publisher=World Organization for Animal Health | url =http://www.oie.int/eng/press/en_090428.htm | accessdate =30 April 2009 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090501134026/http://www.oie.int/eng/press/en_090428.htm| archivedate= 1 May 2009 | deadurl= yes}} The first case of the [[H1N1 virus]] was discovered in [[Cairo, Egypt]] on 2 June 20, in a 12-year-old girl coming from the US with her mother. Only the girl was infected and the officials caught the case before letting her out of the airport.{{Citation needed|date=October 2009}} A second and third case were discovered on Sunday 7 June, two students at the [[American University of Cairo]].{{Citation needed|date=October 2009}}{{cite news| url=https://af.reuters.com/article/topNews/idAFJOE5510ED20090602 | work=Reuters | title=Egypt detects first H1N1 flu case: WHO official | date=2 June 2009| accessdate=14 November 2009 }} On 11 June 2 more cases were discovered, bringing the total number of cases to 12.{{cite web|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5iP1qStvCULJ_rKgmloiXfwbJcKGA|title=Toddler latest swine flu case in Egypt|accessdate=12 June 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090616125702/https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5iP1qStvCULJ_rKgmloiXfwbJcKGA| archivedate= 16 June 2009 | deadurl= no}} The swine flu was confirmed in 21 African countries: Egypt, South Africa, Morocco, Algeria, Tunisia, Ethiopia, Côte d'Ivoire, Seychelles, Cape Verde, Libya, Kenya,{{cite web |title=Introduction and Transmission of 2009 Pandemic Influenza A (H1N1) Virus --- Kenya, June—July 2009 |url=https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5841a1.htm |work=Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report |publisher=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) |date=23 October 2009 |accessdate=23 October 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091025120730/http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5841a1.htm |archivedate=25 October 2009 |deadurl=no |df= }} Uganda, Botswana, Zimbabwe, Tanzania, Mauritius, Somalia, Sudan, Namibia, Zambia, Gabon, and Rwanda. The H1N1 virus was a concern in the months leading up to the [[2010 FIFA World Cup]], which took place in June 2010 in South Africa.{{cite web|url=http://health.iafrica.com/healthnews/2256901.htm|title=iafrica.com Winter raises H1N1 fears|work=iAfrica.com|access-date=17 March 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100507122616/http://health.iafrica.com/healthnews/2256901.htm|archive-date=7 May 2010|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en/news/1863/world-cup-2010/2010/02/16/1793220/world-cup-2010-swine-flu-threat-in-mind|title=FINISHED: World Cup 2010: Swine Flu Threat In Mind - Goal.com|work=Goal.com}} ===Asia=== {{Main|2009 flu pandemic in Asia}} {| class="table" style="margin:auto;" |- valign="top" |[[File:H1N1 Asia map.svg|thumb|center|200px|
'''2009 flu pandemic
in Asia'''
{{legend|#000000|Deaths}}{{legend|#cd3412|Confirmed cases}}{{legend|#FFA900|Suspected cases}}{{legend|Silver|No reported cases}}]] |[[File:H1N1 Asia map by confirmed deaths.svg|thumb|center|200px|{{legend|forestgreen|No deaths}}{{legend|#e6e6e6|1+ deaths}}{{legend|#cccccc|5+ deaths}}{{legend|#b3b3b3|10+ deaths}}{{legend|#999999|50+ deaths}}{{legend|#808080|100+ deaths}}]] |} ====Western and Central Asia==== [[File:H1N1 Central Asia map.svg|thumb|left|H1N1 in Central Asia{{legend|#000000|Deaths}}{{legend|#cd3412|Confirmed cases}}{{legend|#FFA900|Suspected cases}}{{legend|Silver|No reported cases}}]] [[File:H1N1 Southwest Asia Map.svg|thumb|left|H1N1 in Southwest Asia{{legend|#000000|Deaths}}{{legend|#cd3412|Confirmed cases}}{{legend|#FFA900|Suspected cases}}{{legend|Silver|No reported cases}}]] On 27 April, Azerbaijan imposed a ban on import of [[animal husbandry]] products from America.{{cite news|url=http://en.trend.az/news/society/health/1462401.html|agency=[[Trend News Agency]]|title=Prevention against "swine flu" stabile in Azerbaijan: minister|date=28 April 2009|accessdate=28 April 2009}} [[AZAL]] took additional safety measures and a sanitary [[quarantine]] unit of the Health Ministry started to operate in [[Heydar Aliyev International Airport]], checking all aircraft and passengers.{{cite news|url=http://en.apa.az/news.php?id=101254|agency=Azerbaijan Press Agency|title=All aircraft and passengers examined at Heydar Aliyev International Airport|date=28 April 2009|accessdate=29 April 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090503171300/http://en.apa.az/news.php?id=101254|archivedate=3 May 2009|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}} On 2 May [[Border checkpoint]]s with disinfection barriers for both cars and pedestrians were installed at the Samur, Shirvanovka and Khan Oba checkpoints in [[Qusar Rayon|Qusar]] and [[Khachmaz Rayon|Khachmaz Raions]].{{cite news|url=http://en.apa.az/news.php?id=101573|agency=[[Azerbaijan Press Agency|APA]]|title=Azerbaijan-Russia border checkpoints pass to medium security|date=2 May 2009|accessdate=2 May 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090503171339/http://en.apa.az/news.php?id=101573|archivedate=3 May 2009|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}} The [[veterinary service]]s at checkpoints intensified their activities while hog farms in the northern regions switched to a closed farming regime. Seventy-seven cases were confirmed in Israel.{{cite news |url=http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1082352.html |title=Two more Israelis test negative for swine flu |publisher=Haaretz |date=1 May 2009 |accessdate=1 May 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090503090752/http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1082352.html| archivedate= 3 May 2009 | deadurl= no}} In response to the outbreak, the Israeli Deputy [[Health Minister of Israel|Minister of Health]], [[Yaakov Litzman]], suggested that out of respect for the religious sensibilities of Jews and Muslims, the flu should be called "Mexican Flu." This was done so as to not confuse the population into thinking that they could not acquire the virus if they did not eat pork.BBC News, [http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/americas/8021301.stm "Israel renames unkosher swine flu"], 27 April 2009 . Retrieved 28 April 2009.{{Citation |publication-date=27 April 2009 |title=Israeli official: Swine flu name offensive |series=Associated Press |publisher=Yahoo News |at=news.yahoo.com |url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20090427/ap_on_re_mi_ea/ml_odd_israel_kosher_flu |accessdate=28 April 2009 |archivedate=2 May 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090502072711/http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20090427/ap_on_re_mi_ea/ml_odd_israel_kosher_flu }} The Israeli government retracted this proposal following Mexican complaints.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/apr/28/mexican-swine-flu-pork-name |title=What's in a name? Governments debate 'swine flu' versus 'Mexican flu' | World news | guardian.co.uk |work=The Guardian |location=London |date= 28 April 2009|accessdate=30 April 2009 | first=Ed | last=Pilkington| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090501104953/http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2009/apr/28/mexican-swine-flu-pork-name| archivedate= 1 May 2009 | deadurl= no}} The first confirmed cases were reported in Kuwait on 23 May, after about 18 people on U.S. military bases tested positive.{{cite web|url=http://www.fayobserver.com/print?id=327234&type=article|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090530175313/http://www.fayobserver.com/print?id=327234&type=article|dead-url=yes|archive-date=30 May 2009|title=Fayetteville Online|date=30 May 2009|publisher=}} On 30 May 2009 the first three cases were confirmed in Lebanon. "One Lebanese man who was in Spain and two Canadians who arrived in Lebanon a week ago are suffering from swine flu," the health minister said. "We put them in quarantine and the blood samples we have taken every day have proven to be positive. The Lebanese man and the two visiting Canadians – a woman and her daughter – were given the proper medical treatment in time and they are well now." The Lebanese Health Minister had previously asked citizens to stop the habit of social kissing, that affected schoolchildren be kept at home and that travel to countries in which cases have been confirmed be avoided.{{cite news|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/lifestyleMolt/idUKTRE53R3D320090428 |title=Lebanese told not to kiss in anti-swine flu drive | Lifestyle | Reuters |publisher=Uk.reuters.com |date=9 February 2009 |accessdate=30 April 2009 |first=Nadim |last=Ladki| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090501145551/http://uk.reuters.com/article/lifestyleMolt/idUKTRE53R3D320090428| archivedate= 1 May 2009 | deadurl= no}} Beirut also banned the import of pork.{{cite web|url=http://foodbizdaily.com/articles/28988-swine-flu-fear-prompts-lebanon-to-ban-pork-imports.aspx |title=News: Swine flu Fear Prompts Lebanon to Ban Pork Imports |publisher=Foodbizdaily.com |date=22 February 1999 |accessdate=30 April 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090503110754/http://foodbizdaily.com/articles/28988-swine-flu-fear-prompts-lebanon-to-ban-pork-imports.aspx| archivedate= 3 May 2009 | deadurl= yes}} In Saudi Arabia, the first case, which affected a Filipino nurse working at [[King Faisal Specialist Hospital and Research Center]], was confirmed on 1 June. The Health Ministry, in cooperation with the hospital, applied the national plan for the prevention of swine flu in accordance with WHO's recommendations. Accordingly, the patient was isolated and treated.{{cite web|url=http://www.spa.gov.sa/English/details.php?id=670933|title=Health Ministry announces detection of a Swine Flu case in Riyadh وكالة الأنباء السعودية|publisher=}} ====Southern Asia==== {| class="table" style="float:right;" |- |[[File:H1N1 South Asia map.svg|thumb|center|H1N1 in South Asia{{legend|#000000|Deaths}}{{legend|#cd3412|Confirmed cases}}{{legend|#FFA900|Suspected cases}}{{legend|Silver|No reported cases}}]] |- |[[File:H1N1 Southeast Asia map.svg|thumb|center|H1N1 in Southeast Asia{{legend|#000000|Deaths}}{{legend|#cd3412|Confirmed cases}}{{legend|#FFA900|Suspected cases}}{{legend|Silver|No reported cases}}]] |} All people entering India via the main airport hubs of [[Mumbai]], New Delhi, [[Kolkata]], [[Ahmedabad]], Goa, [[Jaipur]], [[Kochi, India|Kochi]], [[Chennai]], [[Bangalore]] and [[Hyderabad, Andhra Pradesh|Hyderabad]] were screened. The primary focus was on passengers entering from the US, [[The United Kingdom]], Canada, Mexico, France and New Zealand.{{cite news|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2009-04-28/india/28039180_1_health-secretary-naresh-dayal-swine-flu-health-ministry | title=American & European visitors to be screened for swine flu |work=Times Of India | date=28 April 2009 | first1=Kounteya | last1=Sinha| accessdate=14 November 2009 }} As of 25 October, over 13,000 cases had been confirmed in India, with 444 deaths, starting with a 13-year-old girl's death in the city of [[Pune]], where almost 91 people died.{{cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/videos/news/13-year-old-girl-dies-of-swine-flu-in-Pune-toll-rises-to-8/videoshow/4879963.cms|title=13-year-old girl dies of swine flu in Pune, toll reaches 8| accessdate=11 August 2009|work=The Times Of India }} In the Maldives, a ministerial committee was established to supervise preventive measures to avoid an outbreak. All visitors arriving at the [[Malé]] International Airport and the country's three commercial seaports were screened.{{cite web |title=Maldives prepares for swine flu |author=Ibrahim Mohamed |url=http://www.minivannews.com/news_detail.php?id=6428 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5hLBtXzRT?url=http://www.minivannews.com/news_detail.php?id=6428 |archivedate=7 June 2009 |date=30 April 2009 |accessdate=30 April 2009 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} Pakistan took precautionary measures at its international airports to check passengers coming from affected countries.{{cite web|url=http://www.dawn.com/wps/wcm/connect/dawn-content-library/dawn/news/pakistan/14-pakistan-mobilises-against-swine-flu-officials-zj-04 |title= Pakistan mobilises against swine flu| date=29 April 2009|publisher=The Dawn| accessdate=14 November 2009 }} Doctors checked incoming passengers and allowed entry only to those with no symptoms. Major hospitals were placed on high alert. ====Southeastern Asia==== Since 8 July a total of 207 cases were reported in Brunei.{{cite web|url=http://www.brudirect.com/index.php/200907082062/First-Stories/swine-flu-hits-record-in-brunei-as-more-falls-sick.html|title=Disease Crosses The 200 mark|date=8 July 2009| accessdate=8 July 2009| publisher=Brudirect.com}} The Cambodian Pig Raiser Association told the government it should ban live pig imports. But Khlauk Chuon, the deputy director of Camcontrol at the Ministry of Commerce, said they would only ban live pig imports from affected countries.{{cite web|url=http://www.phnompenhpost.com/index.php/2009042925585/National-news/Regional-flu-cases-cause-concern.html|title=Regional flu cases cause concern |publisher=phnompenhpost.com|accessdate=29 April 2009}} The Indonesian government halted the importation of pigs and initiated the examination of 9 million pigs.{{cite web|url=http://nasional.kompas.com/read/xml/2009/04/27/11120229/cegah.flu.babi.pemerintah.gelar.rapat.koordinasi|title=Cegah flu babi, pemerintah gelar rapat koordinasi|date=27 April 2009|publisher=Kompas newspaper| accessdate=14 November 2009 }} [[Thermal scanner]]s that can detect human body temperature were installed at Indonesian ports of entry.{{cite web|url=http://www.kompas.com/read/xml/2009/04/27/13282547/Takut.Flu.Babi..Indonesia.Hentikan.Impor.Babi|title=Takut flu babi, Indonesia hentikan impor babi|date=27 April 2009|publisher=Kompas newspaper| accessdate=14 November 2009 }} The Lao government bought 10 thermal imaging machines to install at the country's major immigration border checkpoints. The Prime Minister [[Bouasone Bouphavanh]] said masks should be made available and health officials would be assigned to border checkpoints.{{cite web|title=Govt to make swine flu border checks|url=http://www.vientianetimes.org.la/FreeContent/Free_Govt.htm|publisher=Vientiane Times|accessdate=29 April 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090502010026/http://www.vientianetimes.org.la/FreeContent/Free_Govt.htm| archivedate= 2 May 2009 | deadurl= no}} On 22 July, Laos recorded its first death.{{cite news|title=First swine flu death in Laos: Official |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/NEWS/World/Rest-of-World/First-swine-flu-death-in-Laos-Official-/articleshow/4808230.cms |work=Times of India |accessdate=22 July 2009 |date=22 July 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090725225652/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/NEWS/World/Rest-of-World/First-swine-flu-death-in-Laos-Official-/articleshow/4808230.cms |archivedate=25 July 2009 }} In Malaysia, health screenings were carried out on passengers traveling to and from Mexico via sea, air and land beginning 17 April.{{cite web|url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2009/4/26/nation/3775744|title=Malaysia on alert after deadly flu hits Mexico|date=26 April 2009|publisher=[[The Star (Malaysia)|''The Star'' Online]]|accessdate=14 November 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090618031946/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2009%2F4%2F26%2Fnation%2F3775744|archive-date=18 June 2009|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web | url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2009/5/16/nation/20090516113331 | title=A (H1N1): Second confirmed case in Malaysia (Update 4) | date=16 May 2009 | publisher=[[The Star (Malaysia)|''The Star'' Online]] | accessdate=14 November 2009 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090618031957/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2009%2F5%2F16%2Fnation%2F20090516113331 | archive-date=18 June 2009 | dead-url=yes | df=dmy-all }} The Health Ministry's disease control division activated its operations room to monitor the situation and informed medical practitioners treating suspicious cases to inform the district health office immediately.{{cite web|url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/index.php/malaysia/24632-operations-room-activated-to-monitor-swine-flu-|title=Operations room activated to monitor swine flu| date= 26 April 2009|publisher=Malaysian Insider| accessdate=14 November 2009 }} Thermal scanners were installed at [[Kuala Lumpur International Airport]].{{cite web | url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2009/5/15/nation/20090515141134 | title=Malaysia confirms first case of A(H1N1) flu (Update 2) | date=15 May 2009 | publisher=[[The Star (Malaysia)|''The Star'' Online]] | accessdate=14 November 2009 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090519121627/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2009%2F5%2F15%2Fnation%2F20090515141134 | archive-date=19 May 2009 | dead-url=yes | df=dmy-all }} Screenings were imposed in [[Pengkalan Hulu]], at the [[Malaysia-Thailand border|border with Thailand]], in late April.{{cite web| url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2009/4/29/nation/20090429193202 | title=Swine Flu: Screening team stationed at Thai border | date=29 April 2009 | publisher=[[The Star (Malaysia)|''The Star'' Online]]| accessdate=14 November 2009 }} Quarantine rooms were allocated in 28 hospitals{{cite web| url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2009/5/11/nation/3877174 | title=Special quarantine rooms at 28 hospitals for A(H1N1) | date=11 May 2009 | publisher=[[The Star (Malaysia)|''The Star'' Online]]| accessdate=14 November 2009 }} and the country stockpiled more than 2 million doses of [[Tamiflu]], as of May 2009.{{cite web|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/Breaking%2BNews/World/Story/STIStory_371052.html |title=H1N1 flu outbreak: H1N1 flu watch |date=2 May 2009 |work=Straits Times |location=Singapore |accessdate=14 November 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090504073120/http://www.straitstimes.com/Breaking%2BNews/World/Story/STIStory_371052.html |archivedate=4 May 2009 |df= }} Schools were issued strict hygiene procedures on 16 May to contain any outbreak.{{cite web| url=http://thestaronline.com/news/story.asp?file=/2009/5/16/nation/20090516121115 | title=A (H1N1): Schools to follow Health Ministry hygiene procedures | date=16 May 2009 | publisher=[[The Star (Malaysia)|''The Star'' Online]]| accessdate=14 November 2009 }} On 15 May, the Health Ministry confirmed Malaysia's first case: a male student who had arrived via air from [[Newark Liberty International Airport|Newark]].{{cite web| url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2009/5/16/nation/3921680 | title=21-year-old student from US has H1N1 | date=16 May 2009 | publisher=[[The Star (Malaysia)|''The Star'' Online]]| accessdate=14 November 2009 }}{{cite web | url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2009/5/17/nation/20090517102332 | title=Home quarantine for passengers and crew of AirAsia flight (Update) | date=17 May 2009 | publisher=[[The Star (Malaysia)|''The Star'' Online]] | accessdate=14 November 2009 | Panama and Nicaragua reported no fatalities. ===Oceania=== Researchers in Australia and New Zealand reaffirmed that infants under the age of 1 had the highest risk of developing severe illness.{{cite web|author=[[World Health Organization]]|url=http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/rwb.nsf/db900SID/SKEA-7WVHUP?OpenDocument|title=Pandemic (H1N1) 2009 – update 70|date=16 October 2009|publisher=ReliefWeb|accessdate=27 October 2009}} Canadian health officials reported that swine flu is hospitalizing three to four times as many children as regular seasonal flu. {{cite news | url = https://vancouversun.com/health/H1N1+putting+more+children+hospital+than+seasonal+variety/2268189/story.html | title = H1N1 flu putting more children in hospital than seasonal variety | agency = [[Canwest News Service]] | newspaper = [[The Vancouver Sun]] | first = Sharon | last = Kirkey | date = 26 November 2009 | accessdate=7 December 2009 }} [[File:H1N1 Oceania Map.svg|200px|thumb|left|{{legend|#000000|Deaths}}{{legend|#cd3412|Confirmed cases}}{{legend|#ffcd00|Suspect cases}}{{legend|Silver|No cases}}]] [[File:H1N1 Oceania map by confirmed deaths.svg|200px|thumb|right|{{legend|forestgreen|No deaths}}{{legend|#e6e6e6|1+ deaths}}{{legend|#cccccc|5+ deaths}}{{legend|#b3b3b3|10+ deaths}}{{legend|#999999|50+ deaths}}{{legend|#808080|100+ deaths}}{{legend|#666666|500+ deaths}}{{legend|#4d4d4d|1000+ deaths}}{{legend|#333333|5000+ deaths}}]] {{Main|2009 flu pandemic in Oceania}} The first confirmed case in Australia was reported on 9 May.{{cite news|title=First confirmed case of swine flu in Australia |publisher=News.com.au |date=9 May 2009 |url=http://www.news.com.au/story/0,27574,25452286-5018988,00.html |accessdate=9 May 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090511005950/http://www.news.com.au/story/0%2C27574%2C25452286-5018988%2C00.html |archivedate=11 May 2009 |deadurl=yes |df= }} As of 3 July, Australia had 7,290 confirmed cases. The first Australian death was on 19 June and the total death toll reached 20.{{cite web |url=http://www.healthemergency.gov.au/internet/healthemergency/publishing.nsf/Content/3F3956D6384E104ACA2575EB00192925/$File/h1n1-update-20090709.pdf |title=National tally of people being tested for Swine Influenza as at 12 pm, 9 July 2009 |format=PDF |publisher=[[Department of Health and Ageing]] |date=9 July 2009 |accessdate=9 July 2009 }} The alert level was raised from "delay" to "contain", giving authorities in all states the option to close schools.{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/05/23/2579007.htm|title=Rudd defends swine flu threat upgrade|date=23 May 2009|work=ABC News|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|accessdate=23 May 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090527085158/http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/05/23/2579007.htm| archivedate= 27 May 2009 | deadurl= no}} Australia stockpiled 8.7 million doses of Tamiflu and [[Relenza]].{{cite news |url=http://www.theage.com.au/national/70-australians-tested-for-swine-flu-20090428-alvp.html?page=-1 |title=70 Australians tested for swine flu |publisher=AAP |accessdate=28 April 2009 | location=Melbourne | date=29 April 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090430094929/http://www.theage.com.au/national/70-australians-tested-for-swine-flu-20090428-alvp.html?page=-1| archivedate= 30 April 2009 | deadurl= no}} At the beginning of the outbreak airlines were required to report passengers from the Americas with influenza symptoms and nurses were deployed at international airports. On 30 May, New Zealand had 9 confirmed cases and 10 probables. During June cases in New Zealand rose rapidly. On 14 June the Ministry of Health announced a 65% increase in cases in just 24 hours. On 4 July, the Ministry of Health announced the first New Zealand deaths. Three confirmed deaths were confirmed, however two had known underlying medical conditions. The total number of confirmed cases reached 945.{{cite web|title=Influenza A (H1N1) Swine Flu – Update Ninety-five |url=http://www.moh.govt.nz/moh.nsf/indexmh/influenza-a-h1n1-update-ninety-five-040709?Open |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jeGTqIg6?url=http://www.moh.govt.nz/moh.nsf/indexmh/influenza-a-h1n1-update-ninety-five-040709?Open |archivedate=9 September 2009 |deadurl=no |accessdate=5 September 2009 |df=dmy }} Two cases were confirmed in the Pacific Islands. Both cases were confirmed on 15 June, one in the Solomon Islands and another in Samoa.{{cite news|title='Solomon Islands may lack capacity to deal with H1N1 outbreak' says official|url=http://australianetworknews.com/stories/200906/2598896.htm?desktop|date=15 June 2009|accessdate=15 June 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090616122100/http://australianetworknews.com/stories/200906/2598896.htm?desktop|archive-date=16 June 2009|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|url=http://www.rnzi.com/pages/news.php?op=read&id=47175|title=Samoa confirms positive swine flu test for Australian student |date= 15 June 2009|accessdate=15 June 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090618010600/http://www.rnzi.com/pages/news.php?op=read&id=47175|archivedate= 18 June 2009 | deadurl= no}} 5 cases were confirmed in Fiji as of 24 June and 1 case in {{Main|2009-2010 flu pandemic in South America}} In Argentina, as of April, passengers with symptoms arriving from Mexico and United States were required to list where they would be should they experience any symptoms.{{cite news |author=Heguy, Silvina| title= La Argentina ya controla a los pasajeros que llegan a Ezeiza|url=http://www.clarin.com/diario/2009/04/26/elmundo/i-01906060.htm |work= [[Clarín (Argentine newspaper)|''Clarín'']]|date= 26 April 2009|accessdate=28 April 2009|language=Spanish}} In addition, the government stepped up safety checks, and thermal scanners were being used at airports to detect passengers with fever and other influenza symptoms. Flights from Mexico were temporarily suspended.{{cite news |title= Por la gripe porcina, el Gobierno suspende los vuelos con México|url=http://www.clarin.com/diario/2009/04/28/um/m-01907438.htm |work= [[Clarín (Argentine newspaper)|''Clarín'']]|date= 27 April 2009|accessdate=28 April 2009|language=Spanish}} These measures proved to be largely ineffective. As of 22 June, Argentina had 1,213 confirmed cases and 10 confirmed deaths,{{cite web|title=Ministerio de Salud de la Nación |url=http://www.msal.gov.ar/htm/site/alerta-epidemiologico.asp |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jeGK5QC3?url=http://www.msal.gov.ar/htm/site/alerta-epidemiologico.asp |archivedate=9 September 2009 |deadurl=no |accessdate=5 September 2009 |df=dmy }} increasing to 52 confirmed deaths{{cite news|title=Confirman seis muertes más por el virus en la ciudad |url=http://www.lanacion.com.ar/nota.asp?nota_id=1146524&pid=6801339&toi=6256 |work=[[La Nación]] |date=3 July 2009 |accessdate=3 July 2009 |language=Spanish |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jeGPT6DM?url=http://www.lanacion.com.ar/nota.asp?nota_id=1146524&pid=6801339&toi=6256 |archivedate=9 September 2009 |deadurl=no |df= }} and an estimated number of as many as 100,000 infected on 2 July, as confirmed by Minister of Health [[Juan Luis Manzur]].{{cite news|title=Ya hay en el país 100.000 contagiados por la gripe A |url=http://www.lanacion.com.ar/nota.asp?nota_id=1146304&pid=6796181&toi=6256 |work=[[La Nación]] |date=2 July 2009 |accessdate=2 July 2009 |language=Spanish |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jeGLfSiD?url=http://www.lanacion.com.ar/nota.asp?nota_id=1146304&pid=6796181&toi=6256 |archivedate=9 September 2009 |deadurl=no |df= }} As of 14 July, the number of officially recognised cases skyrocketed, with 137 deaths,{{cite news |title= La Argentina es el segundo país en cantidad de muertos por gripe A|url=http://www.lanacion.com.ar/nota.asp?nota_id=1150437&pid=6880178&toi=6256 |work= [[La Nación]]|date= 14 July 2009|accessdate=14 July 2009|language=Spanish}} making the death toll in Argentina the second highest in the world, behind only the US. As of April, Brazilian airports were monitoring arrivals from affected areas, under the direction of the National Sanitary Surveillance Agency (ANVISA). Air crews were trained on signs and symptoms.{{cite press release |title=Ocorrências de casos humanos de influenza suína no México e nos EUA |url=http://portal.saude.gov.br/portal/aplicacoes/noticias/default.cfm?pg=dspDetalheNoticia&id_area=124&CO_NOTICIA=10121|language=Portuguese |publisher=Brazilian Ministry of Health |date=26 April 2009 |accessdate=27 April 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090429172311/http://portal.saude.gov.br/portal/aplicacoes/noticias/default.cfm?pg=dspDetalheNoticia&id_area=124&CO_NOTICIA=10121| archivedate= 29 April 2009 | deadurl= no}} As of 4 June, there were 28 confirmed cases. The first case flu in Chile was confirmed on 17 May.{{cite web|url=http://www.emol.com/noticias/nacional/detalle/detallenoticias.asp?idnoticia=358513|title=Confirman primer caso de influenza H1N1 en Chile|date=17 May 2009|accessdate=17 May 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090520141655/http://www.emol.com/noticias/nacional/detalle/detallenoticias.asp?idnoticia=358513| archivedate= 20 May 2009 | deadurl= no}} On 29 May, the Chilean Health ministry confirmed the number of cases had risen to 226.{{cite web|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-05/30/content_11455221.htm|title=A/H1N1 flu infections rise to 224 in Chile |date=29 May 2009|accessdate=30 May 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090618012249/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-05/30/content_11455221.htm| archivedate= 18 June 2009 | deadurl= no}} On 3 June Chile suffered its first confirmed death, a 37-year-old man from [[Puerto Montt]].{{cite web |url=http://www.emol.com/noticias/nacional/detalle/detallenoticias.asp?idnoticia=360983|title=ISP confirms first swine flu death in Chile|publisher=El Mercurio Online|date=2 June 2009| accessdate=14 November 2009 }} To the date, and since laboratory tests were no longer mandatory, the estimate of cases in Chile reached 500.000 cases.{{cite web|url=http://www.emol.com/noticias/nacional/detalle/detallenoticias.asp?idnoticia=365988 |title=Especialista estima en 500.000 los casos de influenza en Chile |date=6 July 2009 |accessdate=6 July 2009 |publisher=[[EMOL]] |author=EMOL |language=Spanish |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jeHedhB7?url=http://www.emol.com/noticias/nacional/detalle/detallenoticias.asp?idnoticia=365988 |archivedate=9 September 2009 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} On 3 May, Minister Palacio confirmed the first case in Colombia,{{cite news|url=http://elespectador.com/node/138253/|title=Bajan a cuatro los casos de sospecha de gripe porcina en Colombia|date=28 April 2009|accessdate=28 April 2009|publisher=[[El Espectador]]|author=EFE|language=Spanish| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090503085457/http://elespectador.com/node/138253/| archivedate= 3 May 2009 | deadurl= no}} in a 42-year-old, who had recently traveled to Mexico.{{cite news|url=http://caracol.com.co/nota.aspx?id=805147|title=Bajo tratamiento médico y estable se encuentra primer contagiado en Colombia con AH1N1|date=2 May 2009|accessdate=3 May 2009|publisher=[[Caracol Radio]]|language=Spanish}} According to Palacio, only one of 18 tests sent to [[Atlanta]] was positive. The patient was isolated and put under medical treatment. On the same day, Palacio stated there were 108 suspect cases in the country. On 27 April, the Government declared a "national disaster" state{{cite news|url=http://www.caracoltv.com/node/136917|title=Colombia declara situación de desastre para enfrentar la gripe porcina|date=27 April 2009|accessdate=28 April 2009|publisher=[[Caracol TV]]|language=Spanish| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090503080414/http://www.caracoltv.com/node/136917| archivedate= 3 May 2009 | deadurl= no}} which allowed health authorities to have a special budget.{{cite news|url=http://colombiareports.com/colombia-news/news/3775-colombia-declares-state-of-emergency-over-swine-flu-threat.html|title=Colombia declares state of emergency over swine flu threat|date=27 April 2009|accessdate=28 April 2009|publisher=Colombia Reports| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090429225520/http://colombiareports.com/colombia-news/news/3775-colombia-declares-state-of-emergency-over-swine-flu-threat.html| archivedate= 29 April 2009 | deadurl= no}} The government purchased 400,000 [[oseltamivir]] (Tamiflu) doses, to be distributed through the Social Protection ministry.{{cite news|url=http://www.caracoltv.com/node/137220|title=Medicamento para tratar gripe porcina ya está en Colombia|date=29 April 2009|accessdate=29 April 2009|publisher=[[Caracol TV]]|language=Spanish| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090503080626/http://www.caracoltv.com/node/137220| archivedate= 3 May 2009 | deadurl= no}} Health officials examined arrivals with flu symptoms.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/americas/8022516.stm#americas The world response to flu crisis], BBC News, 28 April 2009. On 29 April, Ecuador closed its borders to Mexican citizens and foreigners of other nationalities arriving from Mexico for 30 days.[http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/notas/594671.html Ecuador restringe por un mes vuelos a México], ''[[El Universal (Mexico City)|El Universal]]'', 29 April 2009. On 15 May, health officials confirmed the first case in Ecuador.[http://www.ecuadorinmediato.com/noticias/especial/104315 ECUADOR HABRIA CONFIRMADO PRIMER CASO DE GRIPE AH1N1] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090518033202/http://www.ecuadorinmediato.com/noticias/especial/104315 |date=18 May 2009 }} On 20 May, the Health Department confirmed 7 more new cases, raising the total to 8,{{cite web|url=http://eluniverso.com/2009/05/20/1/1384/EF26D2D8E533454B8918EAC264EFE819.html|title=Ministra de Salud de Ecuador confirma 8 casos de gripe AH1N1|author=EL UNIVERSO|work=El Universo}} and then to 41.{{cite web|url=http://www.eluniverso.com/2009/06/02/1/1384/EF11A9A1F8CC4B96B4068EF48F380F27.html|title=2 personas más con gripe porcina|author=EL UNIVERSO|work=El Universo}} The first case in Peru was confirmed on 14 May. On 17 May, the second case was confirmed. He had returned from the US on 12 May, showing symptoms only two days later.{{cite news|url=http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/ap/tx/6428563.html |title=Peru confirms 2nd swine flu case in US man |work=Houston Chronicle |date=17 May 2009 |accessdate=17 May 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090519201633/http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/ap/tx/6428563.html |archivedate=19 May 2009 |deadurl=yes }} On 18 May a new case was confirmed, a scholar returning from a trip to Dominican Republic. Another case of a scholar came from the same trip. The student had contact with the third victim and both studied in the same school.{{cite web|url=http://elcomercio.pe/lima/288650/noticia-escolar-infectada-virus-ah1n1-tercer-no-cuarto-caso-peru|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120729055113/http://elcomercio.pe/lima/288650/noticia-escolar-infectada-virus-ah1n1-tercer-no-cuarto-caso-peru|deadurl=yes|title=Escolar infectada con el virus AH1N1 es el tercer y no el cuarto caso…|date=29 July 2012|archivedate=29 July 2012|publisher=}} The Governor of [[Callao]] ordered that all passengers from any infected country be checked before their entry into Peruvian territory. The Peruvian government was to be warned of any case or symptom. This step affected the main port and airport of Peru, located in Callao. The government prepared a special area at the Hospital "Daniel Alcides Carrión" to treat cases.{{cite web|url=http://www.rpp.com.pe/2009-04-24-peru-toma-medidas-para-evitar-el-ingreso-de-la-gripe-porcina-noticia_177656.html|title= Perú toma precauciones con la gripe porcina|publisher=[[Radio Programas del Perú]]|date=24 April 2009|accessdate=25 April 2009|language=Spanish}} Slaughterhouses were inspected and screened incoming passengers from problem areas.{{cite web|url=http://www.livinginperu.com/news/8912 |title=News " Five Peru patients test negative for swine flu – Government discards threat |publisher=Living in Peru |accessdate=30 April 2009 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20090503160816/http://www.livinginperu.com/news/8912 |archivedate=3 May 2009 |deadurl=no |df= }} All commercial flights from Mexico to Peru were suspended on 29 April. In Venezuela, controls were raised at airports to prevent contagion from spreading. Travellers from the United States and Mexico with symptoms were isolated until they cleared. Pig farms in the country were "closely inspected" and medicine stockpiled. On 28 May Health Minister [[Jesús Mantilla]] confirmed the first case in a Venezuelan citizen who flew from Panama. He was isolated and treated.{{cite web|url=http://www.radiomundial.com.ve/yvke/noticia.php?25372|title= Confirman el primer caso de gripe A/H1N1 en Venezuela |publisher=Gobierno Bolivariano de Venezuela: YVKE Mundial|date=28 May 2009|accessdate=28 May 2009|language=Spanish| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090601042852/http://www.radiomundial.com.ve/yvke/noticia.php?25372| archivedate= 1 June 2009 | deadurl= no}} The following day, a second case was confirmed from another person on the same flight.{{cite web|url=http://www.radiomundial.com.ve/yvke/noticia.php?25458|title=Min. Salud confirma segundo caso de influenza A/H1N1 en el país|publisher= Gobierno Bolivariano de Venezuela: YVKE Mundial|date=29 May 2009|accessdate=29 May 2009|language=Spanish| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090601152126/http://www.radiomundial.com.ve/yvke/noticia.php?25458| archivedate= 1 June 2009 | deadurl= no}} ==Reporting bias== Epidemiologists cautioned that the number of cases reported in the early days of an outbreak could be very inaccurate.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/04/28/health/28docs.html?hpw |title=Sound the alarm? A swine flu bind |author=Altman Lawrence K |date=28 April 2009 |work=New York Times |accessdate=30 April 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090503111111/http://www.nytimes.com/2009/04/28/health/28docs.html?hpw| archivedate=3 May 2009| deadurl= no}} Causes included selection bias, media bias and incorrect reporting by governments. [[Selection bias]] in [[epidemiology]] occurs when authorities in different jurisdictions look at differing sets of patient. For example, in the early days of the pandemic, doctors in Mexico may have been concentrating on patients in hospitals, rather than the larger vulnerable population. This may in part explain the higher mortality recorded there. Conversely, it is implausible that few, if any, died in Mexico while Brazil and the United States accumulated hundreds of additional lab-confirmed deaths. [[Media bias]] may have skewed incidence maps based on these media reports. Countries with poor health care systems and poor laboratory facilities may take longer to identify suspected cases, analyse those cases and report them.{{cite news |publisher=Reuters |url=http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/IRIN/2687d9562c28b487c30aca4e889c5e93.htm |title=GLOBAL: No A (H1N1) cases – reality or poor lab facilities? |date=8 May 2009 |accessdate=9 May 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090511130411/http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/IRIN/2687d9562c28b487c30aca4e889c5e93.htm| archivedate= 11 May 2009 | deadurl= no}} Passive data collection methodologies (waiting for the patient to arrive at a health care facility) are considered inferior to active data collection techniques (performing random [[stratified sampling]]) due to selection bias{{cite web |url=http://www.collegeboard.com/prod_downloads/yes/4297_MODULE_19.pdf |title=Observational studies and bias in epidemiology |publisher=College board |format=PDF |year=2004 |accessdate=30 April 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090423151327/http://www.collegeboard.com/prod_downloads/yes/4297_MODULE_19.pdf| archivedate= 23 April 2009 | deadurl= no}} and because laboratory facilities to perform swift genetic tests on patient samples are not widely available. {{As of|2009|07}} there no properly controlled epidemiological studies had been conducted for Action Against Austerity is a grassroots network of groups in Scotland opposing [[Austerity]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://actionagainstausterity.wordpress.com/|title=Action Against Austerity |website=Action Against Austerity|language=en-US|access-date=2016-12-16}}</ref>
The network formed in 2015 from signatories to the "From Yes to Action statement" which was founded by the [[Autonomous Centre of Edinburgh|autonomous centre of Edinburgh]], the Edinburgh section of the [[Anarchist Federation (Britain and Ireland)|Anarchist Federation]], the Edinburgh branch of [[Industrial Workers of the World|The Industrial Workers of The World]] and [[Edinburgh coalition Against Poverty|Edinburgh Coalition Against Poverty]] and all of which are members of the network .<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://edinburghanarchists.noflag.org.uk/2014/11/from-yes-to-action-joint-statement-on-post-referendum-organising/|title=From Yes to Action {{!}} Joint statement on post-referendum organising|website=edinburghanarchists.noflag.org.uk|access-date=2016-12-16}}</ref>
Other members include Dundee Against Welfare Sanctions(DAWS) now called Dundee Against Austerity.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://actionagainstausterity.wordpress.com/2015/05/24/from-yes-to-action-joint-statement-on-post-referendum-organising/|title=From Yes to Action {{!}} Joint statement on post-referendum organising|last=edinburghwobbly|date=2015-05-24|website=Action Against Austerity|access-date=2016-12-16}}</ref>
The IWW Scottish Assembly voted to support "From Yes to action" and so Clydeside(Glasgow) IWW joined along with Edinburgh.

[[File:Société de géographie plaque 04923.jpg|thumb|right|150px|Société de Géographie]] The '''Arab Congress of 1913''' (also known as the "Arab National Congress,<ref>{{cite book|last=Tibi|first=Bassam|title=Arab Nationalism: A Critical Enquiry|year=1981|publisher=St. Martin's Press|isbn=0-312-04716-9|pages=84}}</ref>" "First Palestinian Conference," the "First Arab Congress,<ref name="Thomas 1976 318">{{cite book|last=Thomas|first=David|title=Essays on Islamic Civilization|year=1976|publisher=E.J. Brill|isbn=90-04-04464-7|pages=318|editor=Donald P. Little}}</ref>" and the "Arab-Syrian Congress<ref>{{cite book|last=Dockser Marcus|first=Amy|title=Jerusalem 1913|year=2007}}</ref>") met in a hall of the French Geographical Society ([[Société de Géographie]]) at 184 [[Boulevard Saint-Germain]], [[Paris]] from June 18–23 in Paris to discuss reforms to grant the [[Arabs]] living under the [[Ottoman Empire]] more autonomy. The Arab National Congress, was established by 25 official Arab Nationalists delegates to discuss desired reforms to grant Arabs more autonomy under the Ottoman Empire. It took place at a time of uncertainty and change in the Ottoman Empire: in the years leading up to [[World War I]], the Empire had undergone a [[Young Turk Revolution|revolution]] (1908) and a [[1913 Ottoman coup d'état|coup]] (1913) by the [[Young Turks]], and had been defeated in two wars against [[Italo-Turkish War|Italy]] and the [[First Balkan War|Balkan states]]. The Arabs were agitating for more rights under the fading empire and early glimmers of [[Arab nationalism]] were emerging. A number of dissenting and reform-oriented groups formed in [[Greater Syria]], [[Palestine (region)|Palestine]], [[Constantinople]], and [[Egypt]]. Under [[Zionist]] influence, [[Jewish immigration to Palestine]] was increasing, and England and France were expressing interest in the region, competing for spheres of influence.
[[File:Paris-bld-saint-germain.jpg|250px|thumb|Boulevard Saint-Germain at the corner of Rue de Buci. Buildings shown between the corner of the rue de Buci and rue de Seine are the original North side of the former rue des Boucheries.]] It was under these conditions that a group of students living in Paris called for a Congress to be held to discuss proposed Arab reforms. While the Congress was not ultimately successful in its proposed aims, it was a reflection of events taking place and dynamics that shaped the early 20th century for three continents before [[World War I]] began. Many scholars place the origins of [[Arab nationalism]] during these crucial years that witnessed a dwindling of empires and a build-up of tension surrounding Zionist immigration to Palestine and Arab reaction to it. The whole Congress declared itself ready to struggle to bring the Arab Nation into being by means of revolution. [[Al-Hoda]] Editor and Lebanese League of Progress President, [[Naoum Mokarzel]] started cautiously by saying that: “The Revolution must be literary and reformist”, he continued more aggressively “only the last resort should it be bloody, because the political systems of free nations have been constructed by martyrs and not with printers ink.” »<ref>[https://www.amazon.com/Arab-Nationalism-Between-Islam-Nation-State/dp/0312162863/ref=wl_it_dp_o_npd?ie=UTF8&coliid=I2HL5XJRTDJ9J7&colid=1GGYTSFVBC74S»]</ref>
==Ottoman Empire== The [[Ottoman Empire]] was in a state of decline at the beginning of the 20th century. In 1908, a revolt led by the [[Young Turks]] led to regime change that briefly led to increased freedom of expression until the Turkish crackdown of 1915-1916. Attempts by the regime to contain Western influence, implement an increasingly centralized government, and movement toward the "[[Turkification]]" of Arab lands prompted resistance from parts of the Arab world. [[Balkan Wars|War]] broke out in the [[Balkans]] in October 1912, further weakening Istanbul's hold over its domain. (N)
==Arab nationalism== Scholars disagree over when exactly [[Arab nationalism]] began, but there were glimmers of a distinctive Arab identity beginning to form, partly in response to perceived Ottoman oppression, in the years leading up to the Arab Congress. Particular concerns included the desire to speak Arabic in the public sphere, a decentralized administration (i.e. more local control over administrative matters), and the right for Arab soldiers to serve in their own region, rather than a distant corner of the empire.
===Reform organisations=== A number of reform-minded groups sprung up in these early years before World War I. Many remained secret so as to avoid government infiltration.
* Beirut Reform Society, "Jam'iyyat Beirut al-'Islahiyya," (Beirut, 1912) ** sent a delegation of six to the conference ** members: [[Salim Ali Salam]], Ahmad Bayhum, among others ** wanted French government to pressure the Unionist government to grant desired reforms<ref name="Thomas 1976 318"/>
* The [[Young Arab Society]], "al-Fatat," (Paris, 1911) ** called for the Arab congress in order to "demonstrate the unity and strength of the Arab movement" as well as to discuss reforms (Thomas) ** members: Abd al-Ghani al-Uraysi, [[Jamil Mardam Bey]], and [[Awni Abd al-Hadi]], Palestinian [[Rafiq al-Tamimi]], the Iraqi [[Tawfiq al-Suwaidi]], Ahmad Rustum Haydat, and Ahmad Qadri, among others * Arab League Society, "Jam'iyyat al-Jami'a al-'Arabiyya," (Cairo, 1910) ** [[Rashid Rida]], founder (N) ** secret reform society whose goal was "to promote and safeguard Arab rights." (N) * [[Ottoman Party for Administrative Decentralization]], or "Hizb al-Lamarkaziyyah al-Idariyyah al-Uthmani" (Cairo, 1912) * Al Ahd, "The [[Covenant Society]]" (1914) ** [['Aziz 'Ali al-Misri]], founder and Ottoman Arab officer ** supported unity between Arabs and Turks ** largely consisted of army officers, including Yasin and Taha al-Hashimi, Salim al-Jaza'iri, Ali al-Nashashibi, Salim al-Tabbakh, Mustafa Wasfi, Isma'il al-Saffar, and Nuri al-Sa'id, among others. ** supported a "call for Arab independence...respect for Islamic values...and the institution of the Caliphate." (ayyad) * Ligue de la Patrie Arabe, "League of Arab Patriots," (1904, Paris) ** founded by Najib Azuri ** goal was to free greater [[Syria]] and [[Iraq]] from Turkish domination * [[Committee of Union and Progress]] (CUP) * Literary Society, "[[al-Muntada al-Adabi]]," ([[Istanbul]]) ** 'Abd al-Karim al-Khalil, president ** as many as 1000 members (N) ** composed of Arab expatriate in Istanbul ** al-Khalil was executed for [[treason]] in 1915
==Background== Jewish immigrants had begun arriving in historic Palestine before 1900. By 1913 there was concern among Arab communities that the Zionist settlers desired to settle Arab lands at the exclusion of the Arabs.{{Citation Needed|date=August 2017}} England and France were showing interest in the region as the two empires competed with one another for influence. Scholar David Thomas<ref>{{cite book|title=Essays on Islamic Civilization|year=1976|publisher=E. J. Brill|isbn=90-04-04464-7|pages=317–328|author=David S. Thomas|editor=Donald P. Little}}</ref> contends that many of the reform groups that participated in the conference "...were more suspicious of the intentions of Britain and France in the [[Levant]] than afraid of and hostile to the [[Ottoman Porte]]..." The Congress was held under the auspices of the [[French Ministry of Foreign Affairs]].<ref name="Tibi 1981 84" />
==Congress timeline== * April 4, 1913: al-Fatat invites the [[Ottoman Party for Administrative Decentralization]] and the Muslim Friends Club to send delegates to the Congress.<ref>{{cite book|last=Thomas|first=David|title=Essays on Islamic Civilization|year=1976|publisher=E.J. Brill|isbn=90-04-04464-7|pages=318}}</ref> * April 11, 1913: [[Ottoman Party for Administrative Decentralization]] accepts invitation. * May 30, 1913: Delegates from several groups begin to arrive in Paris. * June 18, 1913: Congress begins. * June 23, 1913: Congress ends.
==Attendees== While there were 25 "official" delegates, many representatives of reform societies attended unofficially. The following is a partial list of both official and unofficial individuals: [[File:AbdalHamidZahrawo.jpeg|thumb|150px|Abd al-Hamid al-Zahrawi]] [[File:Darwaza.jpg|thumb|right|150px|Izzat Darwaza]] * Abd al-Hamid al-Zahrawi (president of Congress and later executed by the Turks<ref name="Tibi 1981 84" /> ) * Salim Ali Salam, Muslim member of Beirut delegation and Executive Committee member of Congress<ref name="Khalidi 1980 310"/> * Shaykh Ahmed Hassan Tabbara, Muslim member of Beirut delegation and Executive Committee member of Congress<ref name="Khalidi 1980 310"/> * Ahmad Mukhtar Beyhum, Muslim member of Beirut delegation<ref name="Khalidi 1980 310">{{cite book|last=Khalidi|first=Rashid|title=British Policy Towards Syria and Palestine|year=1980|pages=310}}</ref> * [[Najeeb Diab]], President, United Syrian Society (New York) * Albert Sursuq, Christian member of Beirut delegation<ref name="Khalidi 1980 310"/> * Ayyub Thabit, Christian member of Beirut delegation<ref name="Khalidi 1980 310"/> * Daud Barakat * George Samné, a Syrian Christian * Iskandar Bey 'Ammun, a Lebanese Christian * [[Izzat Darwaza]], representative from the [[Jamma'in]] subdistrict of [[Nablus]] * Khalil Zaiyniyya, Christian member of Beirut delegation<ref>{{cite book|last=Khalidi|first=Rashid|title=British Policy Towards Syria & Palestine 1906-1914|year=1980|publisher=Ithaca Press London|isbn=0-903729-57-1|pages=309–310}}</ref> * Khayrallah Khayrallah,<ref name="Tibi 1981 84">{{cite book|last=Tibi|first=Bassam|title=Arab Nationalism: A Critical Enquiry|year=1981|pages=84}}</ref> a Syrian supporter of France * Mahbub al-Shartuni (unofficial) * Nadrah Matran (also transliterated as "Nadra Mutran"), a Lebanese Christian * Najib Azouri<ref name="Tibi 1981 84"/> * [[Naoum Mokarzel]] * Rizq Allah Arqash (from [[Beirut Reform Society]]) * Abd al-Karim al-Khalil (official delegate but did not attend sessions) * Abd al-Ghani al-Uraysi, member of Preparatory Committee * Dr. Sa'id Kamil, an Egyptian observer<ref name="Tibi 1981 84" /> * Sami Hochberg, Zionist and unofficial observer<ref>{{cite book|last=Mandel|first=Neville|title=The Arabs and Zionism Before World War I|year=1980|pages=159}}</ref> * Shukri Ghanim, vice-president of Congress, member of Preparatory Committee, and secretary of the [[CUP party]] * [[Tawfiq al-Suwaidi]], an Iraqi member of [[al-Fatat]] * Victor Jacobson, Zionist representative
==Resolutions== According to [[Rashid Khalidi]],<ref>{{cite book|last=Khalidi|first=Rashid|title=British Policy Towards Syria & Palestine 1906-1914|year=1980|publisher=Ithaca Press London}}</ref> the adopted resolutions included making Arabic "an official language in the Arab provinces...the employment of Arab troops in their home provinces except in time of war...stronger locally-controlled provincial government." Also per Khalidi, the resolutions were sent to the [[Quai d'Orsay]]. Perhaps a reflection of their own desired autonomy, the Congress included a "declaration of solidarity with the autonomist demands of the [[Armenians]]" (page 314).
==Aftermath== The Congress did not have a lasting effect, due in no small part to the beginning of World War I. Many of the concerns addressed at the Congress were decided as parts of larger shifts of power during the War. It is impossible to say what directions these proposed reforms would have taken were it not for the war, the fall of the [[Ottoman Empire]] and the [[Balfour Declaration of 1917|Balfour Declaration]]. It is clear, however, that not only did Arabs not gain the freedoms they sought from the Ottomans, but with increased Zionist immigration, the [[Arab Revolt]] of 1936-37, and the founding of [[Israel]] in 1948, that rather the opposite came to pass. The Arab nationalism that came about after [[World War II]] is attributable to factors such as the decline of colonial influence, rather than reforms debated back in 1913.
