{{Global surveillance}}
[[Smart City|Smart cities]] seek to implement [[information and communication technologies]] (ICT) in order to improve the efficiency and sustainability of urban spaces while reducing costs and resource consumption.<ref name=Economist1>{{cite web |url=https://www.economist.com/news/briefing/21585002-enthusiasts-think-data-services-can-change-cities-century-much-electricity?frsc=dg/a |title=Clever cities: The multiplexed metropolis |publisher=The Economist |date=2013-09-07 |accessdate=2015-05-21 }}</ref> In the context of [[surveillance]], smart cities monitor citizens through strategically placed sensors around the urban landscape, which collect data regarding many different factors of urban living. From these sensors, data is transmitted, aggregated, and analysed by governments and other local authorities in order to extrapolate information about the challenges the city faces in sectors such as [[crime prevention]],<ref name=SantaCruz>{{cite news |last=Baxter |first=Stephen |url=http://www.santacruzsentinel.com/general-news/20120226/modest-gains-in-first-six-months-of-santa-cruzs-predictive-police-program |title=Modest gains in first six months of Santa Cruz's predictive police program |work=Santa Cruz Sentinel |date=2012-02-26 |accessdate=2015-05-26 }}</ref><ref name=Economist2>{{cite web |url=https://www.economist.com/news/briefing/21582042-it-getting-easier-foresee-wrongdoing-and-spot-likely-wrongdoers-dont-even-think-about-it |title=Predictive policing: Don't even think about it |publisher=The Economist |date=2013-07-20 |accessdate=2015-05-21 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Berg |first=Nate |url=https://www.theguardian.com/cities/2014/jun/25/predicting-crime-lapd-los-angeles-police-data-analysis-algorithm-minority-report |title=Predicting crime, LAPD-style |work=The Guardian |date=2014-06-25 |accessdate=2015-05-30 }}</ref> traffic management,<ref name="Amsterdam2"/><ref name=Amsterdam>{{cite web|url=http://amsterdamsmartcity.com/projects |title=Amsterdam Smart City ~ Projects |author=Amsterdam Smart City |accessdate=2015-05-30 }}</ref> energy use <ref name=Amsterdam /> and waste reduction. This serves to facilitate better [[urban planning]]<ref name=Hardy>{{cite web |url=http://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/04/19/how-urban-anonymity-disappears-when-all-data-is-tracked/?_r=0 |title=How Urban Anonymity Disappears When All Data Is Tracked |last=Hardy |first=Quentin |work=Bits Blog |publisher=The New York Times |date=2014-04-19 |accessdate=2015-05-21 }}</ref> and allows governments to tailor their services to the local population.<ref name=Southampton>{{cite web |url=http://www.southampton.gov.uk/roads-parking/travel/smartcities-card/ |title=SmartCities card |author=Southampton City Council |accessdate=2015-05-30 }}</ref><ref name=BCN1>{{cite web|url=http://smartcity.bcn.cat/en/new-bus-network.html |title=New bus network |author=BCN Smart City |accessdate=2015-05-30 }}</ref>
Such technology has been implemented in a [[Smart city#Flagship cases|number of cities]], including [[Santa Cruz, California|Santa Cruz]], [[Barcelona]], [[Amsterdam]] and [[Stockholm]]. Smart city technology has developed practical applications in improving effective [[law enforcement]], the optimization of transportation services,<ref name=Metropticon>{{cite journal |title=WELCOME TO THE METROPTICON: PROTECTING PRIVACY IN A HYPERCONNECTED TOWN |journal=Fordham Urban Law Journal |year=2014 |last=Finch |first=Kelsey |last2=Tene |first2=Omer |volume=41 |page=1581 |accessdate=}}</ref> and the improvement of essential infrastructure systems,<ref name=Metropticon /> including providing local government services through e-Governance platforms.<ref name=Paskaleva>{{cite book |last=Paskaleva |first1=Krassimira |title=Smart Cities: Governing, Modelling and Analysing the Transition |chapter=E-Governance as an enabler of the smart city |editor-last=Deakin | editor-first=Mark |publisher=Taylor and Francis |date=2013-08-22 |page=77 |isbn=978-1135124144 }}</ref>
This constant and omnipresent [[data transmission|transmission of data]]<ref name=Hardy /> from disparate sources into a single government entity has led to concerns being raised of these systems turning into ‘electronic [[panopticon]]s’,<ref name=Economist1 /> where governments exploit data driven technologies in order to maximize effective surveillance of their citizens. Such criticism is drawn from privacy factors,<ref name=Metropticon /> as the information sharing flows operate vertically between citizens and the government on a scale that undermines the concept of urban anonymity.<ref name=Metropticon />
== Law enforcement == The most discernible use of smart city technology for Government Surveillance arises in law enforcement, where critics consider the accumulation of intelligence through [[data collection]] strategies key to intelligence-based policing.<ref name=Cahiers>{{cite journal |title=Policing, Surveillance and law in a pre-crime society: Understanding the Consequences of Technology based strategies |journal=Cahiers Politiestudies |year=2011 |last=van Brakel |first= Rosamunde |last2=De Hert |first2=Paul |volume=3 |issue=20 |url=http://www.vub.ac.be/LSTS/pub/Dehert/378.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=2015-05-30 }}</ref> The technology available in smart cities includes extensive [[Closed-circuit television|CCTV]] installations (such as in London and Dubai),<ref name=Metropticon /><ref>{{cite news |last=Barrett |first=David |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/10172298/One-surveillance-camera-for-every-11-people-in-Britain-says-CCTV-survey.html |title=One surveillance camera for every 11 people in Britain, says CCTV survey |work=The Telegraph |date=2013-07-10 |accessdate=2015-05-30 }}</ref> smart traffic sensors in New York<ref>{{cite news |last=Hill |first=Kashmir |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/kashmirhill/2013/09/12/e-zpasses-get-read-all-over-new-york-not-just-at-toll-booths/ |title=E-ZPasses Get Read All Over New York (Not Just At Toll Booths) |work=Forbes |date=2013-12-09 |accessdate=2015-05-30 }}</ref> and [[crime prediction]] software in Santa Cruz, California.<ref name=SantaCruz /> This technology holds the potential to significantly improve the type and volume of information that may be relied upon by law enforcement authorities when dealing with crimes. Most policing technologies developed within smart cities appear to have shifted law enforcement from "displinary" to "actuarial",<ref name=Cahiers /> with less focus on identifying individual criminals in order to ascribe guilt and a tendency to classify and manage groups based on levels of dangerousness.
=== Policing Techniques ===
==== Proactive policing ==== {{Main|Proactive policing}}
[[File:Peak hour traffic in melbourne.jpg|thumbnail|right|Traffic Management is a major focus of proactive policing technologies.]]Garland's culture of control theory has been used to describe the trend towards proactive policing in smart cities.<ref name=Cahiers /> In Palestine, there have been proposals to introduce [[GPS]]-based [[tracking system]]s to cars for the purposes of law enforcement within a modern urban environment.<ref name=GPS>{{cite journal |title=SMART ON-BOARD TRANSPORTATION MANAGEMENT SYSTEM USING GPS/GSM/GPRS TECHNOLOGIES TO REDUCE TRAFFIC VIOLATION IN DEVELOPING COUNTRIES |journal=International Journal of Digital Information and Wireless Communications |year=2014 |last=Tarapiah |first=Saed |last2=Atalla |first2=Shadi |last3=AbuHania |first3=Rajaa |volume=3 |issue=4 |pages=96–105 |url=http://sdiwc.us/digitlib/request.php?article=7ac4779680a8d82fbbfbc133a6eda3d1 |format=PDF |accessdate=2015-05-21 }}</ref> Here, the location and speed of every vehicle is recorded and transmitted to the local authority, with a fine issued if the speed of the car exceeds the limit for more than 10 seconds.<ref name=GPS /> The technology also holds the potential to relay information regarding accidents and traffic jams,<ref name=GPS /> allowing traffic to be rerouted. An extensive camera system in Amsterdam relays data regarding the traffic situation to a central control point,<ref name=Amsterdam2>{{cite web|url=http://amsterdamsmartcity.com/projects/detail/id/58/slug/smart-traffic-management |title=Amsterdam Smart City ~ Smart traffic management |author=Amsterdam Smart City |accessdate=2015-05-30 }}</ref> allowing authorities to warn motorists of incidents ahead or adverse weather conditions.
Such technology has a combined preventative and deterrent effect on motorists committing traffic violations. By controlling the speed of vehicles, authorities may minimize one of the more common risk factors in vehicular crashes.<ref name=ABS>{{cite web |url=http://www.abs.gov.au/AUSSTATS/abs@.nsf/2f762f95845417aeca25706c00834efa/96781e47a4d2d886ca2570ec0073f6a9!OpenDocument |title=Special Features: Motor vehicle traffic accidents |author=Australian Bureau of Statistics |date=2006-03-17 |accessdate=2015-05-30 }}</ref> Similarly, by monitoring the location of vehicles through a mix of GPS and camera technology, authorities are able to react in real time to minimize heavy traffic incidents and therefore the likelihood of crashes.<ref name=Amsterdam2 /> Such technology also enables police and emergency authorities to respond instantly to accidents that may occur. The extended ‘reach’ of the ‘long arm of the law’ could thus improve traffic management and efficiency, reducing energy consumption and improving civilians’ safety.
There is criticism of the use of smart city technology for proactive policing. The constant monitoring of every vehicle's location couples with the panopticon-like concept of continuous law enforcement<ref name=Metropticon /> and introduces a level of individualistic paternalism,<ref name=Metropticon /> where citizens are deemed incapable of obeying traffic laws voluntarily. More controversially, GPS tracking and camera monitoring may be inappropriately suited to other high-risk behaviour (such as drunk driving and fatigue),<ref name=ABS /> which are also major factors in traffic accidents. There are also implementation difficulties, as older vehicles lacking GPS equipment would not appear in data streams, severely reducing the accuracy of potential analyses. There is also the risk of arbitrariness within proactive policing. GPS-based speeding enforcement would hold an individual driving above the speed limit for 9 seconds innocent whilst exceeding the limit for 10 seconds would constitute an offence. Such arbitrary measures do not account for the differences in car performance and remove discretion from law enforcement. Extrapolating this lack of discretion across multiple areas of criminal law, with automatic enforcement being implemented as the norm, the potential for unfair outcomes and public dissatisfaction with such technology becomes evident, due to the relatively high risk of non-accountability by governments using these methods.<ref name=Lyria>{{cite journal |title=Using Big Data for Legal and Law Enforcement Decisions |journal=UNSW Law Journal |year=2014 |last1=Bennett Moses |first1=Lyria |last2=Chan |first2=Janet |volume=37 |issue=2 |page=643 |url=http://www.unswlawjournal.unsw.edu.au/sites/default/files/t1_bennett_moses_and_chan.pdf |accessdate=2015-05-21 }}</ref>
==== Predictive policing ==== {{Main|Predictive policing}}
Predictive techniques in policing are not new, as search warrants are a pre-existing example of authorities acting on the basis of [[Suspicion (emotion)|suspicion]] and prediction in contemporary communities<ref name=Guthrie>{{cite journal |title=Predictive Policing and Reasonable Suspicion |journal=Emory Law Journal |year=2012 |last=Ferguson |first=Andrew Guthrie |volume=62 |issue=2 |page=322 |url=http://law.emory.edu/elj/content/volume-62/issue-2/articles/predicting-policing-and-reasonable-suspicion.html |accessdate=2015-05-21 }}</ref> In the context of smart cities, predictive policing is the use of data analytics to determine potential locations of future crime.<ref name=Guthrie /> This data collection often occurs through smartphones carried around by urban populations. Through location-based services in smartphones, the movements of individuals can be tracked and scrutinized by authorities. This has the potential to be particularly effective in crowd control. By comparing the different velocities of individual smartphone users within a certain location, it is possible for law enforcement authorities to ascertain crowd density.<ref name=Wirz>{{cite journal |title=Probing crowd density through smartphones in city-scale mass gatherings |journal=EPJ Data Science |year=2013 |last=Wirz |first=Martin |last2=Franke |first2=Tobias |last3=Roggen |first3=Daniel |last4=Mitleton-Kelly |first4=Eve |last5=Lukowicz |first5=Paul |issue=1 |pages=1–24 |url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1140/epjds17/fulltext.html |accessdate=2015-05-21 |doi=10.1140/epjds17 |volume=2}}</ref> This allows for targeted crowd management and prediction of dangers related to excessive crowding.<ref name=Wirz /> Police are thus able to take appropriate action (such as information broadcasting) in order to reduce the threat of injuries from incidents (such as crowd stampedes), as well as crowd related crime (such as thefts) from occurring.<ref name=Wirz />
This type of policing also allows for law enforcement agencies to ‘predict’ where, when or by whom a crime may occur in the future and respond accordingly. [[Big data analysis|Big data analytical]] tools are used to identify patterns in crime,<ref name=Guthrie /> allowing authorities to map high risk areas, times and days for certain types of crime. Through such software, police are also able to create profiles of potential criminals and associated behaviours.<ref name=Guthrie /> Developments in technology within smart cities allow for the scope of predictions to be increased as well as the types of responses available to law enforcement bodies.
[[File:Downtown santa cruz, cropped.jpg|thumbnail|left|Santa Cruz has been the site of a number of predictive policing experiments.<ref name=SantaCruz />]]Experiments conducted in response to a ‘predictive policing algorithm’ based on crime data in Santa Cruz, California, enabled police officers to identify the most likely time and place within a certain locality for a particular crime to be committed.<ref name=SantaCruz /> This allowed for targeted patrols to be made with a 4 percent decline in burglaries and 13 additional arrests being recorded within the first 6 months.<ref name=SantaCruz /> These figures are preliminary however, and do not account for unreported crime or crime that was prevented through increased police presence.
Although it is possible to envisage such law enforcement intervention as becoming the norm where smart city surveillance technologies have been adopted and implemented, predictive policing has raised a number of legal and non-legal controversies.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.abs.gov.au/AUSSTATS/abs@.nsf/2f762f95845417aeca25706c00834efa/96781e47a4d2d886ca2570ec0073f6a9!OpenDocument |title=Special Features: Motor vehicle traffic accidents |publisher=Australian Bureau of Statistics |date=2006-03-17 |accessdate=2015-05-30 }}</ref> Firstly, the level of criminal activity in a particular area sufficient to warrant extra patrols is unclear when predicting the commission of offences. The point at which the probability of crime becomes statistically significant is one which legal scholars and courts alike have had trouble defining.<ref name=Metropticon /> Within this framework, there is a degree of arbitrariness upon which the weight of the predictive data analysis must be considered, as high crime areas can only be defined with reference to “low levels of crime”.<ref name=Metropticon />
Further, in the United States, searches and arrests must be made on grounds of reasonable suspicion under the [[Fourth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Fourth Amendment]]. This means that officers must be able to “point to specific and articulable facts” that “warrant the intrusion”, or make a predictive judgment that the person is in possession of an item that related to the commission of an offence. Similar protections, though not constitutionally based, exist in Australia<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/nsw/consol_act/leara2002451/s23.html |title=LAW ENFORCEMENT (POWERS AND RESPONSIBILITIES) ACT 2002 - SECT 23 |author=AustLII |work=New South Wales Consolidated Acts |accessdate=2015-05-30 }}</ref> as well as the UK.<ref>{{cite court |litigants=O'HARA v CHIEF CONSTABLE RUC |vol=1997 2 WLR 1 |court=House of Lords |url=https://www.qub.ac.uk/schools/SchoolofLaw/Research/HumanRightsCentre/Resources/EHRIS/EHRISHumanRightsMaterialsonNorthernIreland/NationalCaseLaw/ncasefilestore/Filetoupload,414776,en.htm }}</ref> The latter was confirmed as binding by the European Court of Human Rights<ref name="Gillan">{{cite court |litigants=GILLAN AND QUINTON v. THE UNITED KINGDOM |court=The European Court of Human Rights |date=2010-01-12 |url=http://www.bailii.org/eu/cases/ECHR/2010/28.html }}</ref> on a number of European nations, which includes civil law states. The ability to formulate such “reasonable suspicion” on the basis of big data algorithms is controversial, with some critics arguing that in the absence of active police corroboration of predictive forecasts, there are insufficient grounds to warrant an arrest.<ref name=Guthrie /> Further, the general nature of predictive forecasts is arguably incompatible with the acceptable standards outlined by the [[Supreme Court of the United States|United States Supreme Court]]<ref name=Guthrie /><ref>{{cite court |litigants=Draper v. United States |vol=358 |reporter=U.S. 307 |court=US Supreme Court |date=1959-01-26 |url=https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/358/307/case.html }}</ref> with respect to specific individuals. Patterns of crime generated through data analytics are unlikely to generate the level of accurate predictive detail required for police officers to effect an arrest, when compared to informed tip offs.<ref name=Guthrie /> While in the US, courts have allowed profiling to be used in stopping and searching persons in the right context,<ref name=Guthrie /> notable judicial dissents<ref>{{cite court |litigants=United States v Sokolow |vol=490 |reporter=U.S. 1 |court=US Supreme Court |date=1989-04-03 |url=https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/490/1/case.html }}</ref> and academic research<ref name=Guthrie /> highlight that profiling lacks probative value. In the UK, a House of Lords Report<ref name=HouseofLords>{{cite conference |title=Surveillance: Citizens and the State |url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/ld200809/ldselect/ldconst/18/18.pdf |format=PDF |booktitle=Volume I: Report |conference=Select Committee on the Constitution |publisher=HOUSE OF LORDS |place=London |date=2009-02-06 }}</ref> recommended that such technology be prohibited from use by local authorities, unless they were tied to the investigation of serious criminal offenses. In addition, a major factor in Europe is that predictive policing technology must be exercised in accordance with legislation that is sufficiently clear on the scope of use (foreseeability) and affords persons adequate legal protection from arbitrary uses of predictive data algorithms.<ref name=Cahiers />
[[File:5.29.10NYPDByLuigiNovi6.jpg|thumbnail|A data-driven stop and frisk program in New York was found to constitute racial profiling.]]Non-legal controversies also arise over the passive [[discrimination]] that predictive policing programs can generate. In New York, a data-driven stop and frisk program was aborted after a US District Court found that the program constituted racial profiling.<ref>{{cite court |litigants=Floyd v. City of New York |vol=959 |reporter=Supp.2d |opinion=540, 562 |court=United States Court of Appeals }}</ref> Roughly 83% of persons stopped under the program were persons of colour.<ref name=Metropticon /> This discrimination was masked through the noise generated by mass data analysis,<ref name=Metropticon /> leading some academics to state that the number of factors within predictive policing algorithms may result in conflicting data and biased sampling.<ref name=Metropticon /> The European Court of Human Rights has also acknowledged the disproportionate targeting of search powers against persons of colour in the UK,<ref name=Gillan /> highlighting the dangers of smart city technology in predictive policing.
== Mass surveillance == {{Main|Mass surveillance}}
The concept of smart cities is inherently tied to mass surveillance. The benefits derived from smart city technology are dependent on constant data flows captured and aggregated by sensors, cameras and tracking applications.<ref name=Metropticon /> This persistence surveillance however, raises a number of privacy issues. Mass surveillance through big data acts in a manner that reduces urban anonymity,<ref name=Metropticon /> due to the breadth of information and potential uses which can be extrapolated when multiple data streams are analysed together by a single governmental entity. Advocates of smart cities (such as [[Vint Cerf]]) state that this is akin to the level of privacy experienced in small towns.<ref>{{citation |last=Cerf |first=Vint |contribution=Keynote Address |title=Internet of Things Workshop |editor-last=Gilley |editor-first=Stephanie |publisher=Federal Trade Commission |place=Washington, DC |pages=118–153 |date=2013-11-19 |contribution-url=http://www.ftc.gov/sites/default/files/documents/public_events/internet-things-privacy-security-connected-world/final_transcript.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=2015-05-30 }}</ref> In contrast, critics state that information sharing in smart cities has shifted from horizontal information flows between citizens to a vertical, unilateral process between citizen and government, reflecting concerns about panopticism.<ref name=Metropticon />
=== Data collection ===
Smart city applications often collate and analyse distinct sources of data in order to improve government services to operate more efficiently and effectively. Urban residents have few alternatives other than to subscribe to these services, particularly when making use of essential infrastructure, and thus indirectly and involuntarily consent to the sensors and surveillance technologies deployed throughout the urban environment through the mere act of residency.<ref name=Metropticon /> In Amsterdam, wireless meters collect data about energy usage,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://amsterdamsmartcity.com/projects/detail/id/61/slug/energy-storage-for-households |title=Amsterdam Smart City ~ Energy storage for households |author=Amsterdam Smart City |accessdate=2015-05-30 }}</ref> while the Mobypark app allows for the advertisement and renting of available parking spaces.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://amsterdamsmartcity.com/projects/detail/id/64/slug/smart-parking |title=Amsterdam Smart City ~ Smart parking |author=Amsterdam Smart City |accessdate=2015-05-30 }}</ref> The information collected across these and over 70 other projects in Amsterdam is stored by the City of Amsterdam via a common IP infrastructure.<ref name=Komninos>{{cite book |last=Komninos |first1=Nicos |title=Smart Cities: Governing, Modelling and Analysing the Transition |chapter=What makes cities intelligent? |editor-last=Deakin | editor-first=Mark |publisher=Taylor and Francis |date=2013-08-22 |page=77 |isbn=978-1135124144 }}</ref> Considering that data from these services is accessible by a primary governmental body it allows for the possibility of data which is collected from these ‘distinct’ sources to be aggregated.<ref>{{cite book |last=O'Reilly |first1=Tim |url=http://chimera.labs.oreilly.com/books/1234000000774/ch02.html |title=Open Government |chapter=Chapter 2: Government as a platform |editor-last=Lathrop |editor-first=Daniel |editor2-last=Ruma |editor2-first=Laurel |publisher=O'Reilly Media |year=2010 |accessdate=2015-05-21 }}</ref>
=== Big data analysis === {{See also|Big data}} Big data often refers to the use of data analysis and mapping algorithms generate valuable insights from seemingly disparate datasets.<ref>{{cite book |last=Mayer-Schonberger |first1=Viktor |last2=Cukier |first2=Kenneth |title=Big Data: A Revolution That Will Transform How we Live, Work and Think |chapter=1 |publisher=Houghton Mifflin Harcourt Publishing |year=2013 |accessdate=}}</ref> The implications of applying such analysis to aggregated data sets are that they allow for a more holistic view of the needs of a particular community to be formed. Within smart cities, this data can be used as a reflexive tool when implemented within the urban ICT framework<ref name=Loet>{{cite book |last=Leydesdorff |first1=Loet |title=Smart Cities: Governing, Modelling and Analysing the Transition |chapter=Triple Helix Model of Smart Cities: A neo evolutionary perspective |editor-last=Deakin | editor-first=Mark |publisher=Taylor and Francis |date=2013-08-22 |page=77 |isbn=978-1135124144 }}</ref> allowing the Government to better meet the goals of smart cities – improved livability, efficiency and sustainability.<ref name=Economist1 /> Such benefits were found in Barcelona, where tracking of residents commuting patterns led to a revamp and simplification of the city’s bus routes.<ref name=BCN1 /> Combined with the implementation of smart traffic lights<ref>{{cite web|url=http://smartcity.bcn.cat/en/smart-traffic-lights.html |title=Smart traffic lights |author=BCN Smart City |accessdate=2015-05-30 }}</ref> that allow for central control, buses in Barcelona now run to a schedule that attempts to minimize the amount of time spent waiting at traffic lights.<ref>{{cite press release |url=http://sydney.edu.au/business/itls/research/2015/yes_you_can_erase_your_bus_network |title=Yes, You Can Erase Your Bus Network and Design a New One. Lessons from Houston, Auckland, and other cities |last=Walker |first=Jarrett |publisher=INSTITUTE OF TRANSPORT AND LOGISTICS STUDIES |agency=The University of Sydney |date=2015-05-12 |accessdate=2015-05-30 }}</ref>
Big data analysis is not without flaws in its approach This is particularly true when applied to law enforcement, or where data is collected without the willing cooperation and consent of parties involved. Critics argue that there is an element of "mythology" surrounding big data that larger data sets offer deeper insights into urban issues with higher levels of accuracy and objectivity.<ref name=Lyria />
==== Reliability ====
The increasing significance attributed to big data analytics, particularly within smart cities, gives rise to a situation where government bodies place an ‘almost faith-based’ reliance upon the veracity of results that have been predicted by analyzing surveilled data.<ref>{{cite journal |title=RE-CONCEPTUALISING PRIVACY AND DISCRIMINATION IN AN AGE OF TALENT ANALYTICS |journal=UNSW Law Journal |year=2014 |last=Burdon |first=Mark |last2=Harpur |first2=Paul |volume=37 |issue=2 |url=http://www.unswlawjournal.unsw.edu.au/sites/default/files/final_t3_de_zwart_humphreys_and_van_dissel.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=2015-05-28 }}</ref>
In the absence of critical insight however, reliance on data alone has little support, as seen in the legal doctrine of reasonable suspicion.<ref name=Guthrie /> Traditionally, decisions to apprehend or search an individual in sole reliance upon personal “hunches” were deemed to fail the legal standard of reasonable cause.<ref name=Guthrie /> In this regard, it is difficult to see how data-driven hunches can be considered more reliable.<ref name=Guthrie /> Both elicit assumptions being made based on inferences drawn from observable data, which can be falsified or otherwise inaccurate, undermining the integrity of the process.<ref name=DeZwart>{{cite journal |title=Surveillance, Big Data and Democracy: Lessons for Australia from the US and UK’ |journal=UNSW Law Journal |year=2014 |last=De Zwart |first=Melissa |last2=Humphreys |first2=Sal |last3=Van Diesel |first3=Beatrix |volume=37 |issue=2 |url=http://www.unswlawjournal.unsw.edu.au/sites/default/files/t2_burdon_and_harpur.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=2015-05-28 }}</ref>
Critics of the increasing role played by data-based surveillance for the purposes of law enforcement foresee that such reliance could lead to issues in prosecuting individuals based on a probability-based crime system.<ref name=Guthrie /> Furthermore, such a system holds the potential for conclusions to be drawn by attributing weighting to certain characteristics of an individual – an approach which could inadvertently mask any discriminatory agendas held by law enforcement bodies potentially targeting certain minorities.<ref>{{cite press release |url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/sites/default/files/docs/big_data_privacy_report_may_1_2014.pdf |format=PDF |title=Big Data: Seizing Opportunities, Preserving Values |author=Executive Office of the President |date=2014-05-01 |accessdate=2015-05-28 }}</ref> Adding to the potential for discrimination, many big data algorithms often create new categories that exceed the scope of regulations designed to prevent against the unfair or discriminatory use of data.<ref name=DeZwart />
Outside law enforcement, critics argue that smart cities facilitate a shift to [[e-governance]] platforms, often at the expense of physical interactions with citizens.<ref>{{cite book |last=Deakin |first1=Mark |title=Smart Cities: Governing, Modelling and Analysing the Transition |chapter=Embedded Intelligence of Smart Cities |editor-last=Deakin | editor-first=Mark |publisher=Taylor and Francis |date=2013-08-22 |page=77 |isbn=978-1135124144 }}</ref> While e-governance can improve service delivery and expand the ability to collect data from a single platform,<ref name=Paskaleva /> such processes may be at the expense of competitiveness and based merely on a technology push for more data sources and [[data aggregation|aggregation]] mechanisms.<ref name=Komninos /> As a result, the desire for increased surveillance undermines a fundamental aim of most smart cities to improve efficiency and effectiveness, as the citizens’ desire for certain ICT applications is ignored at the expense of further data aggregation. An example of this controversy has arisen in the UK, where proposals for a Scottish identity card were met with public outcry,<ref>{{cite news |last=Carrell |first=Severin |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2015/mar/02/scottish-identity-database-plans-privacy-risk-ministers-warned |title=Scottish identity database plans carry privacy risk, ministers warned |work=The Guardian |date=2015-03-03 |accessdate=2015-05-30 }}</ref> while similar cards have been implemented in Southampton<ref name=Southampton /> with little trouble, as many city services are provided in exchange for data collection.
=== Privacy and autonomy === [[File:Surveillance cameras.jpg|thumb|left|In some situations, privacy may be lessened by surveillance.]]
The normalization of the collection and aggregation of big data<ref name=Metropticon /> by Governments raises issues of [[privacy]] and [[autonomy]]. Part of this is fuelled by [[feature creep]], where technologies and applications that were perceived to be ‘creepy’ until recently have now become socially acceptable.<ref name=Metropticon /> Much of the concern surrounds the inconvenience and inability for citizens to opt out of new technologies where they form part of essential government services, as there are few alternatives.<ref name=Metropticon /> Should an individual wish to appear “off the grid” they are forced to employ a range of tedious measures (such as paying in cash only and not utilizing a mobile phone) in order to reduce their data footprint.<ref name=OffTheGrid>{{cite web |url=http://www.offthegridnews.com/privacy/how-to-stay-off-the-surveillance-radar/ |title=How To Stay Off The Surveillance Radar |last=Jennings |first=Daniel |work=OffTheGridNews |accessdate=2015-05-24 }}</ref> Despite this, such tactics would only minimize and not eliminate their collectable data.<ref name=OffTheGrid />
Privacy concerns are raised where the data collected may be capable of linking to or identifying an individual,<ref name=Wilson>{{cite journal |title=The collision between Big Data and privacy law |journal=Australian Journal of Telecommunications and the Digital Economy |year=2014 |last=Wilson |first=Stephen |volume=2 |issue=3 |ssrn=2548079 |accessdate=}}</ref> particularly when collated from multiple information sources. The storage of data by governments remains opaque, while the potential for cross-sharing data across government services often means that data is accessible by parties that the provider did not intend to share the data with.<ref name=Metropticon /> By mere participation as a member of an urban community, particularly through the use of essential urban services and infrastructure, an individual is placed at risk of having their data shared amongst multiple platforms and users. While individually such data may not identify the person providing it, when combined with other data in the set, such data may be considered as [[personally identifiable information]] (PII), and thus fall under strict privacy laws.<ref name=Wilson /> The constantly evolving uses of smart cities technology do not often fit neatly into privacy law frameworks,<ref name=Wilson /> which may be extremely broad, like in Australia,<ref name=ALRC>{{cite web |url=http://www.alrc.gov.au/publications/6.%20The%20Privacy%20Act%3A%20Some%20Important%20Definitions/what-not-%E2%80%98personal-information%E2%80%99 |title=The Privacy Act: Some Important Definitions |author=Australian Law Reform Commission |publisher=Australian Government |accessdate=2015-05-30 }}</ref> where a discussion paper published by the Australian Law Reform Commission confirmed that anonymised data may still be PII.<ref name=ALRC /> Similar regimes exist in the United States<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gsa.gov/portal/content/104256 |title=Rules and Policies - Protecting PII - Privacy Act |author=US General Services Administration |publisher=US Government |date=2014-12-19 |accessdate=2015-05-30 }}</ref> and the European Union (see: [[Data Protection Directive]]). In Europe, Government technology that interferes on privacy must be based on a "pressing social need" or otherwise "necessary in a democratic society" and be proportional to the legitimate aims espoused.<ref>{{cite court |litigants=S. AND MARPER V. THE UNITED KINGDOM |court=The European Court of Human Rights |date=2008-12-04 |url=http://hudoc.echr.coe.int/sites/eng/pages/search.aspx?i=001-90051}}</ref> This means that authorities implementing smart cities regimes are at risk of violating privacy laws if appropriate safeguards are not taken. The European Court of Human Rights has held that surveillance mechanisms (including those implemented in smart cities technologies) can violate the right to privacy, especially where domestic legislation does not define the scope or manner of surveillance.<ref>{{cite court |litigants=LIBERTY AND OTHERS v. THE UNITED KINGDOM |court=The European Court of Human Rights |date=2008-07-01 |url=http://hudoc.echr.coe.int/sites/eng/pages/search.aspx?i=001-87207 }}</ref> Conversely, individuals may find that their data has been used illegally in the implementation of smart cities technology. As much smart city technology is based on open platforms that are often outsourced<ref name=Metropticon /> to private citizens and corporations, there are massive risks that PII may be unlawfully shared to third parties. Compounded with the relative opaqueness of data storage by governments, critics argue that individual privacy can be curtailed massively through residence in a smart city with little recourse for individuals.<ref name=Metropticon />
Government surveillance is arguably driven by paternalistic desires to protect citizens,<ref name=Metropticon /> however the individualistic and tailor-made benefits delivered by smart city technology may reduce autonomy. This holds particularly true in light of the shift towards predictive policing that occurs within the smart city environment. Whilst nobly intended, such unilateral actions by a Government may be seen as oppressive<ref name=Metropticon /> – with the omnipotent role assumed by the Government seen as giving rise to that of a panoptic institution.<ref name=Metropticon /> Modern cities are increasingly valuing privacy and digital security, as evidenced by the latest “The Economist Safest Cities Index 2015”,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://safecities.economist.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/EIU_Safe_Cities_Index_2015_white_paper-20.02.15.pdf |format=PDF |title=The safe cities index 2015 |work=Intelligence Unit |publisher=The Economist |date=2015-02-20 |accessdate=2015-05-30 }}</ref> where a Digital Security metric was incorporated alongside traditional measures of safety such as Personal Security and Health.
=== Panopticism === {{See also|Panopticism|Panopticon}}[[File:Panopticon.jpg|thumb|250px|[[Multiview orthographic projection#Elevation|Elevation]], [[Multiview orthographic projection#Section|section]] and [[Multiview orthographic projection#Plan|plan]] of Jeremy Bentham's Panopticon penitentiary, drawn by [[Willey Reveley]], 1791]] The English philosopher [[Jeremy Bentham]] created a circular prison design, known as the [[Panopticon]], whereby prisoners knew that they were capable of being observed at any time without their knowledge – thus affording the prison officers a position of omnipresence.<ref>{{cite book |last=Bentham |first1=Jeremy |title=Proposal for a New and Less Expensive mode of Employing and Reforming Convicts |location=London |year=1798 |accessdate=}}</ref>
The French philosopher [[Michel Foucault]] re-conceptualized the notion of a panopticon as a metaphor for a ‘disciplinary society’, wherein power relations (and imbalances) can be defined and reinforced.<ref name=Discipline>{{cite book |last=Foucault |first1=Michel |title=Discipline and Punish: The Birth of the Prison |year=1975 }}</ref> In such a society power is seen to approach its ideal form by increasing the number of people who can be controlled.<ref name=Discipline />
In this regard, the development of smart cities and the resulting increase in the surveillance capacity of the Government gives rise to conditions which mirror that of the disciplinary society described by Foucault. To this end, the development of smart cities are seen by its critics to foreshadow a larger societal shift - particularly the role adopted by the Government - towards mass surveillance, paternalism, discipline and punishment as a means to attain social order,<ref name=Discipline /> particularly in the United States, where the “Internet of Things” is being used to collect increasingly specific data.<ref name=Metropticon /> The [[commodification]] of surveillance in exchange for services has tended to normalise data collection and create indifference to panoptic developments in technology.<ref name=Giroux>{{cite journal |year=2015 |last=Giroux |first=Henry |title=Totalitarian Paranoia in the Post-Orwellian Surveillance State |journal=Cultural Studies |volume=29 |issue=2 |pages=108–140 |doi=10.1080/09502386.2014.917118}}</ref> One of the major issues with Panopticism in the Smart Cities context is that the 'surveillance gaze' is mediated by the selective biases of the operators of any application or technology, as was shown by a study on the use of CCTV cameras in the UK, where the "usual suspects" tended to be targeted more frequently.<ref name=Cahiers /> In [[Durban]], this panoptic "gaze" extends based on CCTV operator intuition due to a normalisation of the characteristics of criminals.<ref name=Hentschel>{{cite journal |year=2007 |last=Hentschel |first=Christine |title=Making (In)Visible: CCTV, Living Cameras, and Their Objects in a Post-Apartheid Metropolis |journal=International Criminal Justice Review |volume=17 |issue=4 |pages=289–303 |doi=10.1177/1057567707311583}}</ref> Compounding these issues, digitally based panopticism usually views the "visibility" of undesirable characteristics as the problem, and often fails to adequately address matters that are invisible to the surveillance gaze.<ref name=Hentschel />
=== Police state ===
{{See also|Surveillance state}}
If a shift toward mass surveillance came to fruition, it could give rise to the development of an [[Mass surveillance#Electronic police state|electronic police state]] as a result of the increased surveillance capabilities and law enforcement activities. This represents a distinct narrowing of the purpose of surveillance to that of maintaining social order via improved law enforcement. Van Brakel argues that these changes have already taken place, and that the focus of police has gradually moved towards "front-loading" their intelligence systems with relevant knowledge that can be later sorted and used,.<ref name=Cahiers /> Supporting this institutionalised shift, the House of Lords in the UK argued in 2009 that an advantage of surveillance activities is the ability for the government to provide a more tailored approach to governance,<ref name =HouseofLords /> and by extension, law enforcement.
== Solutions ==
In seeking a middle ground between the societal benefits afforded by big data and the resulting loss of privacy and autonomy, academics have proposed a number of solutions.<ref name=Metropticon /> Deakin argues that “smart cities” are not simply those that utilize ICT, but where such intelligence is tailored to meet the needs of citizens through community and environmental drivers.<ref name=DeakinIntro>{{cite book |last=Deakin |first1=Mark |title=Smart Cities: Governing, Modelling and Analysing the Transition |chapter=Introduction to smart cities |editor-last=Deakin | editor-first=Mark |publisher=Taylor and Francis |date=2013-08-22 |page=15 |isbn=978-1135124144 }}</ref> Komninos refers to the three layers of intelligence in smart cities<ref name=Komninos /> as the artificial intelligence of smart city infrastructure, the collective intelligence of the city’s institutions and the intelligence of the city’s populations. By integrating these layers in the implementation process, smart cities may be able to overcome the issues of government opacity that plague them. One of the issues with establishing a legal framework for smart city technology is determining whether to take a technology-specific or technology-neutral approach.<ref name=Nicholls>{{cite journal |title=Sketching and validating the location-based services (LBS) regulatory framework in Australia |journal=Computer Law and Security Review |year=2013 |last=Abbas |first=Roba |last2=Michael |first2=Katina |last3=Michael |first3=M.G. |last4=Nicholls |first4=Rob |volume=29 |issue=3 |pages=576–589 |url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/237011560_Sketching_and_validating_the_location-based_services_%28LBS%29_regulatory_framework_in_Australia |accessdate=2015-05-28 }}</ref> Many technologies have developed too rapidly to be covered by a single technology-specific regime, while a technology-neutral approach risks being too ambiguous to encourage use or development of the regulated technology.<ref name=Nicholls /> Further, most applications are too benign to be regulated, while other more controversial technologies tend to be enabled by the creation of legislation, such as the ''[[Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act 2000]]'', which established scenarios where police were able to carry out surveillance, with or without authorisation.<ref name = Cahiers /> A challenge to these laws is currently pending in the European Court of Human Rights,<ref>{{cite court |litigants=BIG BROTHER WATCH AND OTHERS V. THE UNITED KINGDOM |court=The European Court of Human Rights |date=2013-07-04 |url=http://hudoc.echr.coe.int/sites/eng/pages/search.aspx?i=001-140713}}</ref> reinforcing the difficulty of establishing a suitable legal regime. One potential legal solution in the UK has been the development of the tort of misuse of private information,<ref>{{cite court |litigants=CAMPBELL V MGN LTD |court=House of Lords |date=2004 |url=http://www.bailii.org/uk/cases/UKHL/2004/22.html}}</ref> which the English Court of Appeal held could potentially be breached by data collection, for which damages may be claimed.<ref>{{cite court |litigants=Vidal-Hall v Google Inc |court=England and Wales Court of Appeal |date=20q5 |http://www.bailii.org/ew/cases/EWCA/Civ/2015/311.html}}</ref>
Studies conducted by Deakin and Campbell in 2005 identified three types of interaction between citizens and smart cities.<ref name=Cooper>{{cite book |last=Cooper |first1=Ian |last2=Lombardi |first2=Patrizia|last3=Deakin |first3=Mark|title=Smart Cities: Governing, Modelling and Analysing the Transition |chapter=The IntelCities community of practice |editor-last=Deakin | editor-first=Mark |publisher=Taylor and Francis |date=2013-08-22 |page=15 |isbn=978-1135124144 }}</ref> They concluded that citizens desire accessible and reliable information and seamless and responsive governments during transactions.<ref name=Cooper /> Further, any consultation with the community needed to be transparent and based on democratic engagement and accountability.<ref name=Cooper /> Bennett Moses et al. hold that the success of data-driven technologies is based on technical, social and normative dimensions.<ref name=Lyria /> This means that smart city technologies must satisfy citizens of their effectiveness, have a major beneficial impact that encourages uptake and align with generally acceptable ethics and values.<ref name=Lyria />
=== Access ===
A potential solution to bridge the divide between the competing benefits and costs of big data surveillance is to turn the management of personal information into a ‘joint venture’.<ref name=Tene>{{cite journal |title=Big Data for All: Privacy and User Control in the Age of Analytics |journal=Northwestern Journal of Technology and Intellectual Property |year=2013 |last=Tene |first=Omer |last2=Polonetsky |first2=Jules |volume=11 |issue=5 |pages=263–270 |url=http://scholarlycommons.law.northwestern.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1191&context=njtip |accessdate=2015-05-28 }}</ref> Increasing awareness of how, where and why data is collected by the Government establishes the groundwork for a non-adversarial approach to the use of data within smart cities.<ref name=Tene /> [[File:Barcelona collage.JPG|thumbnail|Barcelona is a city that has embraced smart city technology while maintaining public access.]]This process minimizes perceptions of secrecy,<ref name=Metropticon /> and cities that invest in multiple points of access, such as Barcelona with its Open Government platform<ref>{{cite web|url=http://smartcity.bcn.cat/en/barcelona-open-government.html |title=Open government |author=BCN Smart City |accessdate=2015-05-30 }}</ref> have seen growth in the use of smart city applications.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://smartcity.bcn.cat/en |title=Barcelona Smart City |author=BCN Smart City |accessdate=2015-05-30 }}</ref>
Furthermore, this process has developed to allow individuals to access their own data in a usable format,<ref name=Tene /> as seen through Barcelona’s Open Data project.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://smartcity.bcn.cat/en/open-data.html |title=Open data |author=BCN Smart City |accessdate=2015-05-30 }}</ref> In this way autonomy is regained both in relation to awareness of how an individual is affected by the collection of data as well as participation in the actual application of this data to generate information, as new technologies are developed.
=== Accountability ===
In addition to general awareness of the intended purpose of data collection ‘before the fact’, accountability processes ‘after the fact’ are also required.<ref name=Metropticon /> A potential measure is for responsible parties to be notified where some sort of discriminatory decision is made, thus allowing appropriate action to be taken.<ref>{{cite news |last=Wolf |first=Christopher |last2=Polonetsky |first2=Jules |url=http://www.futureofprivacy.org/wp-content/uploads/Wolf-and-Polonetsky-An-Updated-Privacy-Paradigm-for-the-%E2%80%9CInternet-of-Things%E2%80%9D-11-19-2013.pdf |format=PDF |title=An Updated Privacy Paradigm for the "Internet of Things" |work=The Future of Privacy Forum |date=2013-11-19 |accessdate=2015-05-28 }}</ref> In data-driven processes, particularly in the fields of law enforcement, it is difficult to attribute responsibility to a single body or source, as often the information is derived from a number of different locations.<ref name=Cahiers /> Further, opacity is often essential to predictive policing technologies, as transparency may encourage potential offenders to alter their behaviour to avoid detection.<ref name=Lyria />
Transparency processes however remain crucial to ensure that a panoptic view or electronic police state cannot be imposed, as it allows for a review of how decisions are made in relation to them and what criteria this is based upon. Accountability is particularly relevant in the implementation stage
==== Implementation ====
The implementation stage of smart city technology is considered to be crucial, as the applications and platforms must be grounded in the “social capital, environmental and cultural attributes of the communities they represent”.<ref name=DeakinAl>{{cite journal |title=From Intelligent to Smart Cities |journal=Journal of Intelligent Buildings International: From Intelligent Cities to Smart Cities |last=Deakin |first=Mark |last2=Al Waer |first2=Husam |volume=3 |issue=3 |doi=10.1080/17508975.2011.586671 |pages=140–152}}</ref> Paskaleva notes that e-governance platforms are particularly suited to democratically generating community support where residents are able to participate in the [[decision making]] and implementation process.<ref name=Paskaleva /> Confirming this, studies by Deakin et al. highlight that community backlash to smart city technology is minimized where e-government services are co-designed by governments and communities.<ref name=Cooper /> An example of collaboration at an extreme level was seen in Bletchley Park, where the Nazi Enigma cypher was decoded in what is often referred to as the first smart city.<ref name=Komninos /> More recently, citizen participation has been encouraged in Edinburgh,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.myedinburgh.org.uk |title=The City of Edinburgh Community Network |work=myEdinburgh |accessdate=2015-05-30 }}</ref> where citizens are invited to ICT ‘taster’ sessions in local venues, enabling them to learn about the planning, development and design of new smart city technologies.<ref name=DeakinAl /> Such partnerships incorporate elements of democracy<ref name=DeakinAl /> and highlight how digitally inclusive decision making generates the requisite level of trust to support the implementation of smart city technology. Trust acts as an empowering and engaging mechanism for citizens according to Finch and Tene.<ref name=Metropticon /> This empowerment intelligence allows citizens to upskill<ref name=Komninos /> and assist in the development of innovative smart city networks, addressing areas not contemplated by authorities. In Hong Kong, such development takes place in the Cyberport Zone,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cyberport.hk/en/about_cyberport/about_overview |title=About Cyberport |publisher=Hong Kong Cyberport Management Company Limited |accessdate=2015-05-30 }}</ref> while in Amsterdam, “Smart Citizens Labs”<ref>{{cite web|url=http://amsterdamsmartcity.com/news/detail/id/565/slug/amsterdam-smart-citizens-lab-3 |title=Amsterdam Smart City ~ Smart citizens lab |author=Amsterdam Smart City |accessdate=2015-05-30 }}</ref> are designed for interaction between citizens and government. These mechanisms have resulted in large levels of enthusiasm for smart city technology,<ref name=Paskaleva /> as evidenced by the numerous crowd-sourced Amsterdam Smart City projects to date.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://amsterdamsmartcity.com/ |title=Amsterdam Smart City |author=Amsterdam Smart City |accessdate=2015-05-30 }}</ref>
[[File:Kistavictoriahotelnr1 Publish.jpg|thumbnail|[[Kista]] has implemented smart city technology using the Triple Helix Model with positive outcomes. ]]The Triple Helix Model for Smart cities, combining university, industry and government<ref name=Loet /> in the development process is regarded as a potential benchmark for smart city development and implementation. Kourtit et al. advance that this model implements the knowledge generated from collaboration to tailor smart city applications to market needs.<ref>{{cite book |last=Kourtit |first1=Karima |last2=Lombardi |first2=Patrizia |last3=Deakin |first3=Mark |last4=Caragliu |first4=Andrea |last5=Del Bo |first5=Chiara |last6=Nijkamp |first6=Peter |last7=Giordano |first7=Silvia |title=Smart Cities: Governing, Modelling and Analysing the Transition |chapter=Advanced Triple Helix Network Framework for Smart Cities Performance |editor-last=Deakin | editor-first=Mark |publisher=Taylor and Francis |date=2013-08-22 |page=15 |isbn=978-1135124144 }}</ref> Empirical studies conducted on smart cities in the Netherlands compared the level of ICT penetration to the city’s level of smartness under the Triple Helix Metric, finding a strong positive correlation. A live example of the Triple Helix Model in practice can be seen in the Kista Science City business cluster in Stockholm.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://international.stockholm.se/International-Relations/professional-study-visits/8-ict-information-and-communication-technology1 |title=ICT (Information and Communication Technology) |author=City of Stockholm |publisher=Stockholms stad |accessdate=2015-05-30 }}</ref> Underpinned by the Stokab Model of government provisioned dark fibre,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ictregulationtoolkit.org/en/toolkit/notes/PracticeNote/3244/ |title=Models for Infrastructure Sharing: Sweden’s Stokab |author=ICT Regulation Toolkit |accessdate=2015-05-30 }}</ref> more than 1000 companies<ref name=Kista>{{cite web |url=http://stockholmitregion.com/2012/11/12/stockholms-it-nodes-part-1-kista-science-city/ |title=Stockholm’s IT nodes part 1: Kista Science City |work=Stockholm IT Region |date=2012-11-12 |accessdate=2015-05-30 }}</ref> including multinational [[Ericsson]],<ref>{{cite book |last=Kim |first1=Junmo |title=Globalization and Industrial Development |date=2005-07-10 |page=73 |isbn=978-1469723938 }}</ref> the Royal Institute of Technology (KTH) and Stockholm University reside in Kista,<ref name=Kista /> which has grown to become the largest corporate area in Sweden. The success of Kista highlights the usefulness of the Triple Helix Model in Smart City implementation and provides a potential platform for cities seeking to introduce smart city technology in a manner that optimizes resident uptake.
=== Anonymity ===
When considering the potential for privacy law breaches, particularly within the smart cities context containing a vast scope of data that is available to the Government, data may often need to be de-identified to maintain privacy.<ref name=Metropticon /> Whilst this may make it difficult to reconcile data collected from multiple services, it could still allow for the useful collection and aggregation of data for defined purposes. The E-CAF system (Common Assessment Framework),<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.protectingchildren.org.uk/cp-system/child-in-need/caf |title=Common Assessment Framework |author=Coram Children's Legal Centre |accessdate=2015-05-30 }}</ref> where a database of all children assessed by government services (including police, social services and schools) is maintained by the UK Government, highlights how anonymity is fading due to data-driven technologies.<ref name=Cahiers /> The system allows authorities to predict which children will commit crime in the future and allow them to intervene, based on a number of risk factors and profiling.<ref name=Cahiers /> It is evident that citizens captured by the database as children will no longer be "anonymous" members of society. Given the potential Government presumption that parties unwilling to share their information are inherently suspicious,<ref name=Cahiers /> the difficulty of maintaining anonymity in modern smart cities is clearly quite high.

Marina Borensztein }} '''Mauricio Borensztein''' (27 April 1927 – 11 January 1996), known by the stage name '''''Tato Bores''''', was an [[Argentine]] film, theatre and television comedian, who specialized in [[political satire|political humor]]. His ironic TV [[monologue]]s, delivered at a fast pace, became a reference point for generations of [[People of Argentina|Argentines]]. == Biography == He was born into a family of [[Polish Jewish ]] heritage. He took his first steps into the humor field in 1957, after the [[Revolución Libertadora|fall]] of [[Juan Perón]], debuting in state-owned [[Canal 7 Argentina|Channel 7]]. When in character, he wore dress coat, white bow tie and a deliberately badly cut wig, and waved a cigar. Besides the monologues, at some point during each show he pretended to dial the number of the [[Casa Rosada]] and speak to the [[President of Argentina|President]] (whoever it was at the time), asking pointed questions or commenting on uncomfortable news. Near the end of his life, Borensztein abandoned the weekly show format and resorted to "special programmes" every month or sometimes more often. In one of these, he appeared as Dr. Helmut Strasse, "argentinologist", an [[archeology|archeologist]] specialized in the lost land of Argentina, which had sunk into the Atlantic Ocean 500 years before the fictional time frame of the show. The show was a humorous [[mockumentary]] about the downfall of Argentina where Borensztein, speaking in a mixture of [[Yiddish language|Yiddish]], [[German language|German]] and some odd words in Spanish, [[Overdubbing|overdubbed]] into straight Spanish by a narrator, commented on the latest findings and theories while he toured a digging site. Before the broadcast of one of the programmes, federal judge María Servini de Cubría was warned that the show contained an ironic comment about a ridiculously low fine she had received for mishandling a case. Servini ordered the offending segment to be cut out, and forbade Borensztein to mention her name. This violated [[free speech]], since the programme had not been broadcast and she had not verified it was criminally offensive. Borensztein received overwhelming support from the [[art]]istic community of Argentina, but respected the judicial order, from then on referring to the judge as "the unnameable" or as ''Jueza ==History== [[File:Duvalier (cropped).jpg|thumb|right|[[Papa Doc Duvalier]] created the ''Tontons Macoutes'' because he perceived the military to be a threat to his power.]]
After the [[July 1958 Haitian coup d'état attempt]] against President [[François Duvalier]], he purged the army and law enforcement agencies in Haiti and executed numerous officers as he perceived them as a threat to his regime. To counteract this threat, he created a military force that bore several names. In 1959, his paramilitary force was called the ''Cagoulards'' ("Hooded Men").<ref name="Galván">{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6AdAEQi2WZwC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=Latin American Dictators of the 20th Century: The Lives and Regimes of 15 Rulers |author=Galván, Javier A. |page=100 |year=2012 |isbn=9781476600161 |accessdate=9 April 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DLQv3ZGQGqoC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=Social Resilience and State Fragility in Haiti |editor=Verner, Dorte |page=68 |year=2007 |isbn=9780821371886 |accessdate=9 April 2017}}</ref> They were then renamed to Milice Civile (''Civilian Militia''), and after 1962, Volontaires de la Sécurité Nationale (''Volunteers of the National Security'', or VSN).<ref name="Galván"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8RNvAAAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=The Prophet and Power: Jean-Bertrand Aristide, the International Community, and Haiti |author=Dupuy, Alex |page=35 |year=2006 |isbn=9781461645368 |accessdate=9 April 2017}}</ref> They began to be called the ''Tonton Macoute'' when people started to disappear for no apparent reason.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=I78wBwAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=Antillanité, créolité, littérature-monde |editor=Constant, Isabelle |editor2=Mabana, Kahiudi C. |page=114 |year=2013 |isbn=9781443846325 |accessdate=9 April 2017}} {{fr}}</ref> This group answered to him only.
Duvalier authorized the ''Tontons Macoutes'' to commit systematic violence and [[Human rights in Haiti|human rights]] abuses to suppress political opposition. They were responsible for unknown numbers of murders and [[sexual violence in Haiti|rapes in Haiti]]. Political opponents often disappeared overnight, or were sometimes attacked in broad daylight. ''Tontons Macoutes'' stoned and burned people alive. Many times they put the corpses of their victims on display, often hung in trees for everyone to see and take as warnings against opposition. Family members who tried to remove the bodies for proper burial often disappeared themselves. Anyone who challenged the VSN risked assassination. Their unrestrained [[state terrorism]] was accompanied by corruption, extortion and personal aggrandizement among the leadership. The victims of ''Tontons Macoutes'' could range from a woman in the poorest of neighborhoods who had previously supported an opposing politician to a businessman who refused to comply with extortion threats (ostensibly as donations for public works, but which were in fact the source of profit for corrupt officials and even President Duvalier). The ''Tontons Macoutes'' murdered between 30,000 and 60,000 Haitians.<ref name="Henley 2010">{{cite news |last=Henley |first=Jon |date=14 January 2010 |title=Haiti: a long descent to hell |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/jan/14/haiti-history-earthquake-disaster |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150715012830/http://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/jan/14/haiti-history-earthquake-disaster |archive-date=15 July 2015 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
[[Luckner Cambronne]] led the ''Tontons Macoute'' throughout the 1960s and the beginning of the 1970s. His cruelty earned him the nickname "Vampire of the Caribbean". This particular name was earned by one of his endeavors of extorting plasma from locals for sale. Luckner did this through his company "Hemocaribian" and shipped five tons of plasma per month to US Labs. He would also go on to sell cadavers to medical schools after buying them from Haitian hospitals for $3 per corpse. When the Hospital could not supply this the local funeral homes would be used.<ref> Abbott, E. (2011). Haiti: A shattered nation. New York, NY: Overlook Duckworth. https://books.google.com/books?id=7JumcQAACAAJ&dq=haiti+a+shattered+nation&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjejte3vsLdAhVQVK0KHX_5BEkQ6wEIMDAB</ref> In 1971, President Duvalier died and his widow [[Simone Duvalier|Simone]], and son [[Jean-Claude Duvalier]] ordered Cambronne into exile. Cambronne moved to [[Miami, Florida]], USA where he lived until his death in 2006.<ref name="Charles 2006">{{cite news |url=http://www.miami.com/mld/miamiherald/news/obituaries/15634693.htm |title=Obituary: Luckner Cambronne |last=Charles |first=Jacqueline |date={{date|2006-09-26}} |newspaper=Miami Herald |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090711014218/http://ijdh.org/pdf/RoundupSept30-October112006.pdf#page=43 |archive-date=11 July 2009 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
When [[François Duvalier]] came to power in 1957 [[Haitian Vodou|Vodou]] was becoming celebrated for its purely Haitian heritage by the Intellectuals, or the [[Griots]] after having been let go for years by those with education. <ref>Filan, Kenaz (2007). "1.2. The Roots of Haitian Vodou". The Haitian Vodou Handbook: Protocols for Riding with the Lwa. Rochester, Vermont: Destiny Books. p. 21. {{ISBN|978-1-59477-995-4}}. LCCN 2006028676. OCLC 748396065. OL 8992653W.</ref> The ''Tonton Macoute'' was heavily influenced by [[Haitian Vodou|Vodou]] tradition with denim uniforms resembling clothing like [[Azaka Medeh]] the patron of farmers and the use of the machete in symbolic reference to [[Ogou]] a great general in Vodou tradition. <ref> Get to know a Lwa: Kouzen Zaka. (n.d.). Retrieved September 15, 2018, from http://www.manbomary.com/?p=80 </ref><ref> Ogou- Vodou, Voodoo Spirit, Lwa of the Nago Nation. (n.d.). Retrieved September 15, 2018, from http://www.ezilikonnen.com/lwa-voodoo-spirits/ogou/</ref>
Some of the most important members of the ''Tontons Macoute'' were [[Haitian Vodou|Vodou]] leaders. This religious affiliation gave the ''Tontons Macoute'' a kind of unearthly authority in the eyes of the public. From their methods to their choice of clothes, [[Haitian Vodou|Vodou]] always played an important role in their actions. The ''Tonton Macoutes'' wore straw hats, blue [[denim]] shirts and dark glasses, and were armed with [[machete]]s and guns. Both their allusions to the supernatural and their physical presentations were used with the intention of instilling fear and respect.<ref name="Filan 2007"/><ref name="Schmidt 2011">{{cite book |last=Schmidt |first=Bettina E. |title=The Blackwell Companion to Religion and Violence |series=Blackwell Companions to Religion |volume=42 |date=2011 |publisher=John Wiley & Sons |isbn=978-1-4443-9573-0 |page=121 |chapter=5. Anthropological Reflections on Religion and Violence |lccn=2011002516 |oclc=899182009 |ol=16190447W |editor-last=Murphy |editor-first=Andrew R. |chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MF2Oxz3a0XwC&pg=PT121}}</ref><ref name="Kellough 2008">{{cite thesis |last=Kellough |first=Gretchen Elizabeth |date=2008 |title=''Tisseroman'': The Weaving of Female Selfhood within Feminine Communities in Postcolonial Novels |type=PhD |chapter=5. Mythological and Fantastic Female Communities § Breath, Eyes, Memory |publisher=ProQuest |isbn=978-0-549-50778-9 |page=202 |oclc=466441492 |location=Ann Arbor |chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bNLG1G2SnpkC&pg=PA202}}</ref> Even their title of Tonton Macoute was embedded in Haitian lore of a bogeyman who took children away in his satchel or his Makoute.<ref>Filan, Kenaz (2007). "1.2. The Roots of Haitian Vodou". The Haitian Vodou Handbook: Protocols for Riding with the Lwa. Rochester, Vermont: Destiny Books. p. 21. {{ISBN|978-1-59477-995-4}}. LCCN 2006028676. OCLC 748396065. OL 8992653W.</ref>
The ''Tontons Macoute'' were a ubiquitous presence at the polls in the [[Haitian presidential referendum, 1961|1961 election]], in which Duvalier's official vote count was an "outrageous" and fraudulent {{nowrap|1,320,748 to 0}}, electing him to another term.<ref name="Abbott 1991 ">{{cite book |last=Abbott |first=Elizabeth |author-link=Elizabeth Abbott |title=Haiti: The Duvaliers and Their Legacy |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ql5qAAAAMAAJ |edition=Rev. and updated |date=1991 |publisher=Simon & Schuster |location=New York |isbn=978-0-671-68620-8 |page=103 |lccn=90024770 |oclc=22767635 |ol=1680900W |orig-year=1st pub. 1988}}</ref> They appeared in force again at polls in 1964, when Duvalier held [[Haitian constitutional referendum, 1964|a rigged referendum]] that declared him [[President for Life]].{{citation needed|date=March 2014}}
==Legacy== In 1985 the United States began to shut down funds to Haitian aid cutting nearly a million dollars from it within a year. Nonetheless the regime pushed forward and even had a national party for the ''Tontons Macoute''. ''Tonton Macoute'' day was July 29, 1985 and amongst festivities the group was bestowed new uniforms and was honored by all of [[Baby Doc]]s Cabinet. In exuberance of celebration the ''Tonton Macoute'' went out into the streets and shot twenty-seven people in total for the national party. <ref>Haiti: A shattered nation. New York, NY: Overlook Duckworth. https://books.google.com/books?id=7JumcQAACAAJ&dq=haiti+a+shattered+nation&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjejte3vsLdAhVQVK0KHX_5BEkQ6wEIMDAB</ref>
The lack of funds coming to the ''Tonton Macoute'' was result of being intercepted by the [[Duvalier dynasty]] who were sometimes taking nearly eighty percent of international aid to Haiti, then turning around to only pay forty-five percent of the debts the country owed. This continued until the ''Tonton Macoute'' were left on their own when [[Baby Doc]] fled the country with an estimated $900m. <ref>Henley, J. (2010, January 14). Haiti: A long descent to hell. Retrieved September 15, 2018, from https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/jan/14/haiti-history-earthquake-disaster</ref>
The ''Tonton Macoutes'' remained active even after the presidency of "Papa Doc" Duvalier's son "Baby Doc" ended with the [[Anti-Duvalier protest movement]] 1986.<ref name="Kellough 2008"/> Massacres led by paramilitary groups spawned from the ''Macoutes'' continued during the following decade. The most feared paramilitary group during the 1990s was the [[Front for the Advancement and Progress of Haïti]] (FRAPH), which ''[[Toronto Star]]'' journalist Linda Diebel described as modern ''Tonton Macoutes'', and not the legitimate political party they claimed to be.<ref name="COHA"/>
Led by Emmanual Constant, FRAPH differed from the ''Tonton Macoute'' in their denial to submit to the will of a single authority and their cooperation with regular military forces.<ref>COHA. (n.d.). The Tonton Macoutes: The Central Nervous System of Haiti's Reign of Terror. Retrieved September 15, 2018, from http://www.coha.org/tonton-macoutes/</ref> FRAPH extended its reach far outside that of the Hatian state and had offices present in [[New York City|New York]], [[Montreal]] and [[Miami]] until its disarmament and disband in 1994.<ref>Pike, J. (n.d.). Military. Retrieved September 15, 2018, from https://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/haiti/fraph.htm</ref>
==Representation in other media== * ''[[The Comedians (novel)|The Comedians]]''<ref name="Greene 1966">{{cite book |last=Greene |first=Graham |author-link=Graham Greene |date=1966 |title=[[The Comedians (novel)|The Comedians]] |publisher=The Viking Press |location=New York |asin=B0078EPH2C |lccn=66012636 |oclc=365953 |ol=106070W |type=book}}</ref> (1966) is about the struggle of a former hotel owner against the Tonton Macoute. It was adapted into a [[The Comedians (1967 film)|feature film]] starring [[Richard Burton]], [[Elizabeth Taylor]], [[Peter Ustinov]] and [[Alec Guinness]]. *''[[Ton-Ton Macoute!]]'', a 1970 album by [[Johnny Jenkins]]. *"[[Heaven Knows (Robert Plant song)|Heaven Knows]]," a song by [[Robert Plant]] on his album ''[[Now and Zen]]'', references the Tonton Macoute. *''[[The Serpent and the Rainbow (film)|The Serpent and the Rainbow]]'' (1988), a horror film directed by [[Wes Craven]], loosely based on [[The Serpent and the Rainbow (book)|the book of the same name]], deals with [[Haitian Vodou]] and Duvalierist political repression. * ''[[The Dew Breaker]]''<ref name="Danticat 2004">{{cite book |last=Danticat |first=Edwidge |author-link=Edwidge Danticat |date=2004 |title=[[The Dew Breaker]] |edition=1st |publisher=Knopf |location=New York |isbn=1-4000-4114-7 |lccn=2003060788 |oclc=52838918 |ol=1806976W}}</ref> (2004) is a novel by [[Edwidge Danticat]] that features the ''Tonton Macoute'' as important in the plot. * Prior to her solo career, [[Sinéad O'Connor]] sang in a band called {{not a typo|Ton Ton}} Macoute.<ref name="McNeil 1990">{{cite magazine |last=McNeil |first=Legs |author-link=Legs McNeil |date=April 1990 |title={{not a typo|Sinead}} |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GJ2P1hu6nToC&pg=PA54 |magazine=[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]] |volume=6 |issue=1 |page=54 |issn=0886-3032}}</ref> * The Tonton Macoute is also mentioned in [[Dexter (season 1)|season 1]], [[Father Knows Best (Dexter)|episode 9]] of the popular television series ''[[Dexter (TV series)|Dexter]]''. In the episode, an ex-Cagoulard is recognized and killed by Miami-Dade police sergeant [[James Doakes]], who was formerly stationed in Haiti as an Army Ranger. * [[Don Byron]] mentions the Tonton Macoute while describing Haitian immigrant Abner Louima's brutal interrogation by the [[N.Y.P.D.|NYC Police]] in his song "[[Morning 98 (Blinky)]]" from the 1998 album ''[[Nu Blaxploitation]]''. * The track "Tonton Macoutes" appears on the 1987 album ''Coup d'État'' by [[Muslimgauze]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.discogs.com/Muslimgauze-Coup-DEtat/master/321879|title=Muslimgauze - Coup D'Etat|website=Discogs|access-date=2016-09-22}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.muslimgauze.org/releases/coupLP.html|title=Muslimgauze.org - Discography - Coup D'Etat|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> * In the 2016 video game ''[[Mafia III]]'', the New Bordeux Haitian Mob is composed mainly of Haitian refugees, led by [[François Duvalier]]'s ''Macoutes''. * In the television series ''The Thick of It'', the character Malcolm Tucker jokes in response to why he is so quiet, is due to his "time with the Haitian death squads". * Mentioned in Dexter season 1 and the book

revision.text: {{about|areas of classified information and document classification|operation of traffic signalling devices|traffic-light signalling and operation|other uses|Traffic light (disambiguation)}} {{Underlinked|date=September 2016}} The '''Traffic Light Protocol''' (TLP) was originally created in the early 2000s by the UK Government's National Infrastructure Security Coordination Centre (NISCC, now Centre for Protection of National Infrastructure - CPNI){{Cite web|url=http://publications.tno.nl/publication/34616508%2FoLyfG9/luiijf-2015-sharing.pdf|title=Sharing Cyber Security Information|last=Luiijf; Kernkamp|first=|date=March 2015|website=|publisher=TNO|access-date=2016-10-25}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.trusted-introducer.org/ISTLPv11.pdf|title=ISTLP - Information Sharing Traffic Light Protocol|last=Stikvoort|first=Don|date=11 November 2009|website=|publisher=Trusted Introducer|access-date=2016-10-25}} to encourage{{cite web|url=https://www.oecd.org/sti/40761118.pdf|title=OECD: Development of Policies for Protection of Critical Information Infrastructures|publisher=Oecd.org|accessdate=2015-11-19}}{{cite web|url=http://marc.info/?l=bugtraq&m=122754275122010&w=2|title='Re: OpenSSH security advisory: cbc.adv' - MARC|date=|publisher=Marc.info|accessdate=2012-11-25}} (alt source [http://www.securityfocus.com/archive/1/498577/30/13690/flat SecurityFocus archive entry]) greater sharing of [[Information sensitivity|sensitive]] information. The fundamental concept is for the originator to signal how widely they want their [[information]] to be circulated beyond the immediate recipient. It is designed to improve the flow of information between [[Individual|individuals]], [[Organization|organizations]] or [[Community|communities]] in a controlled and trusted way. It is important that everyone who handles TLP-labeled communications understands and obeys the rules of the protocol. Only then can trust be established and the benefits of information sharing realized. The TLP is based on the concept of the originator labeling information with one of four colors to indicate what further [[dissemination]], if any, can be undertaken by the recipient. The recipient must consult the originator if wider dissemination is required. A number of current specifications for TLP exist: * From ISO/IEC, as part of the Standard on Information security management for inter-sector and inter-organizational communications{{Cite web|url=http://www.iso.org/iso/home/store/catalogue_ics/catalogue_detail_ics.htm?csnumber=42509|title=ISO/IEC 27010:2012 - Information technology -- Security techniques -- Information security management for inter-sector and inter-organizational communications|last=|first=|date=2012|website=|publisher=ISO/IEC|access-date=2016-10-25}} * From US-CERT, which is intended to provide a publicly available simple definition[https://www.us-cert.gov/tlp Traffic Light Protocol (TLP) Matrix and Frequently Asked Questions] * From the Forum of Incident Response and Security Teams (FIRST), which published version 1.0 of its consolidated TLP document on August 31, 2016.[https://www.first.org/newsroom/releases/20160831 FIRST announces Traffic Light Protocol (TLP) version 1.0)] arising from a Special Interest Group it created to ensure that interpretations of TLP are consistent, and clear expectations exist across user communities. == Summary of TLP's four colours and their meanings== There are four colors (or traffic lights):{{cite web |url=http://www.ccip.govt.nz/incidents/tlp.html |title=Incidents | Traffic Light Protocol |publisher=CCIP |date= |accessdate=2012-11-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130205072939/http://ccip.govt.nz/incidents/tlp.html |archivedate=2013-02-05 |df= }} * '''RED - personal for named recipients only''' :In the context of a meeting, for example, RED information is limited to those present at the meeting. In most circumstances, RED information will be passed verbally or in person. *'''AMBER - limited distribution''' :The recipient may share AMBER information with others within their organization, but only on a ‘need-to-know’ basis. The originator may be expected to specify the intended limits of that sharing. *'''GREEN - community wide''' :Information in this category can be circulated widely within a particular community. However, the information may not be published or posted publicly on the Internet, nor released outside of the community. *''' WHITE  - unlimited''' :Subject to standard copyright rules, WHITE information may be distributed freely, without restriction. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[https://www.first.org/tlp first.org] *[http://www.us-cert.gov/tlp us-cert.gov] [[Category:Classified information]] [[Category:Information sensitivity]]
